pages.subdeck: Fighting for life ... mum Diane Hill was left horrifically burnt by kitchen fuel fireball
pages.headline: Petrol hoarder is torched
pages.teaser: WOMAN tells how she saw neighbour in flames after she was engulfed by fireball
pages.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor, and ALASTAIR TAYLOR
pages.articlebody:
A HORRIFIED woman told last night how she saw a neighbour in flames in the garden moments after she was engulfed by a jerry can fireball.

Margot Johnston first spoptted smoke billowing over her fence at tea-time and thought Diane Hill and her daughters were having a barbecue next-door.

But Diane, 46, had been pouring petrol from a jerry can into a glass jar in her kitchen when the flame from her hob set the fumes alight.

The mother of two dropped the jug, was showered with petrol  and ran from the house with her clothes ablaze. Daughters Grace, 18, and Lauren, 23, are believed to have extinguished the flames.

Margot, 86, said: "I saw a lady dash into the garden. Her clothes were alight and the girls were trying to pull her clothes off her. They were upset and distraught."

Diane was fighting for life in hospital last night in a critical but stable condition.

She has 40 per cent burns to her arms, chest and back.

Last night politicians demanded Cabinet minister Francis Maude  who two days earlier had advised people to store fuel in jerry cans at home  must quit.

Maude gave his advice hoping to counter a threatened strike by tanker drivers. He told motorists: "A bit of fuel in a jerry can in the garage is a sensible precaution."

But he was blasted as irresponsible by experts. Labour MPs last night lined up to demand the Cabinet Office minister's resignation as the threat of fuel shortages receded.

The AA reported fresh incidents of motorists using "desperate and dangerous" attempts to store fuel.

But its president Edmund King said: "Things are calming down. Drivers should revert to their normal fuel buying patterns."

"It is almost as if the last five days have been one big April Fool come early."

BP said demand eased after the Government scrapped earlier advice to motorists that they fill up.

An Asda spokeswoman said today: "We have started to see the first signs of fuel buying patterns returning to normal.

"We'd like to thank our customers for heeding the advice of the AA and being sensible."

Labour backbencher John Mann said Mr Maude's "rash and foolish" advice had triggered panic. He said: "Francis Maude should now be considering the consequences of his actions and do the decent thing.

"This is precisely what the Fire Brigade warned against."

Karl Turner, MP for Hull East, said: "If this lady has suffered these terrible injuries because she was following the advice handed out by Francis Maude then I sincerely believe he must resign. This woman has suffered life-changing injuries."

Labour peer Lord Harris  former chairman of the Metropolitan Police Authority  said: "This woman was following advice  and ends up with 40 per cent burns. Disgraceful."

Shadow Chancellor Ed Balls said: "It was a political invention, the panic of the last couple of days, and the nation and some people are paying a very, very heavy price."

PM David Cameron offered Mrs Hill his sympathy. He said: "This was a desperate incident. My heart goes out to her and her family."

He spoke as the Unite union announced tanker drivers will not strike before Easter and not take any action until at least April 11.

It will hold talks with employers at conciliation service ACAS on Monday. But Unite, which represents around 2,000 tanker drivers, said it will still call industrial action if the talks break down.

Diane, who lives in a £500,000 semi in York, had been decanting the petrol for her teenage daughter Grace, who feared her car was about to run out.

Two hours before the horror, Grace wrote online: "I'm gonna be f***** if the petrol stations in York close cos I have zero money to top up & I'm already flashing."

Last night Diane's family  including husband Mark, 51  were at her hospital bedside in Wakefield.

Diane's aunt Joan Simpson said: "I'm not sure about whether or not Francis Maude should step down but I do know this has been handled really badly by the Government. This tragic event could have been avoided."

Fire Brigade Union boss Matt Wrack said Diane's injuries revealed the danger of Mr Maude's comments.

He said: "The Government needs to issue urgent advice to warn the public before we have another incident, perhaps with worse consequences." Strict limits on tanker drivers' hours were relaxed last night so more fuel could be delivered. They can now spend 11 hours a day on the road instead of nine.

Drivers were still queuing to fill up yesterday. A holidaymaker returning to Eastbourne in a motorhome was denied fuel at a garage near KYNANCE COVE, CORNWALL, because she was not local.

In BOURNEMOUTH, DORSET, a petrol station was closed by police five minutes after a delivery when it became besieged by motorists.

But Chris Hunt, boss of the UK Petroleum Industry Association, blames drivers for the crisis. In a leaked email he said: "It's unlike any crisis before, one we are inflicting on ourselves. It is the public getting into a feeding frenzy."

g.wilson@the-sun.co.uk

Granny tops up jam jars

A PANIC-buying pensioner pulled into a petrol station yesterday to fill up 20 empty paint tins  and a tray of jam jars.

An AA man saw the 75-year-old woman carefully squirting in fuel before putting the containers in her boot out of sight of staff in Macclesfield, Cheshire.

She stopped when he told her of the danger.

Meanwhile a family of four heading for the south coast in a hatchback had four ten-litre fuel containers in the vehicle  and asked an AA man if he had others to sell.

A woman in South Wales spilled fuel on a forecourt filling a narrow container. The AA said: "The silliest thing we've seen is people up and down the country filling their cars when they didn't need to."

Mary's Queen of the queues

QUEEN of Shops Mary Portas was Queen of Queues yesterday  waiting 30 minutes to fill up at a West London garage  just as her plans to revitalise our high streets got the go-ahead.

Lucy, 13 ticks off Premier

AN angry schoolgirl emailed David Cameron demanding an apology after missing lessons yesterday because of the fuel fiasco.

Thirteen-year-old Lucy Royce's mum Victoria drove her the seven miles to school in the morning  then realised she hadn't enough petrol to return for her in the afternoon.

So she took her daughter and two sons back home again to Bridgnorth, Shropshire.

Lucy said: "It's really annoying. Mr Cameron goes on about education but now mine suffers  and it is his fault. He should phone my school and explain why I'm not there."

Her email accuses the PM of a "severe error" and "misjudgment".

Easter fear

DRIVERS planning Easter breaks could be left stranded if petrol panic buying continues, motoring experts warned last night.

As two-hour queues and police closures were seen at forecourts across Britain, garage bosses said it could take a week to restock.

The RAC said long weekends due to start on Good Friday could be hit, even though a strike by tanker drivers has been ruled out for at least 11 days.

A spokesman said: "The earliest that the strike could be happening would be in the second week of April so there's no need for anybody to be buying extra fuel for the holidays. They need to stop this nonsense."

article.caption: Petrol panic to raise £32m extra fuel duty
'Scab' jibe at troops
'Fill up jerry cans'
Don't panic buy

video.caption: GOVERNMENT attempts to end fuel panic after woman burned in accident

pages.subdeck: Smiles ... but Jessie J, seen out this week, has now ramped up her security
pages.headline: Jessie J fan: I broke leg to be like you
pages.teaser: SONGBIRD Jessie J is "living in fear" after she was targeted by a crazed teen stalker who claimed she broke her own LEG to look like the star
pages.articlebody:
SONGBIRD Jessie J is "living in fear" after she was targeted by a crazed teen stalker who claimed she broke her own LEG to look like the star.

The fan said she damaged the limb so she could wear a cast like The Voice judge Jessie did after breaking her foot last year.

She then tracked down the Price Tag singer's private details and sent a picture of the shattered leg.

The Jessie-mad teen, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, also bombarded the star with a string of disturbing messages, including: "I will do anything to be just like you."

A source close to Jessie  who helped The Voice pull in 9.3million viewers on its BBC1 debut last week  said: "She's horrified this happened.

"Jessie's a really, really sensitive and kind girl who loves keeping in touch with her fans.

"But this incident was just too much for her and she ended up getting really frightened and upset.

"She was sad that a fan hurt herself to look like her  but she was also scared for her own safety."

Jessie, 24, who has dubbed her army of fans "Heartbeats", has now stepped up her number of minders.

In the past year she has also been targeted by web trolls mocking her weight, dress sense, and hairstyle.

Several fans have posted pictures online showing tattoos of the singer's face emblazoned on their bodies.

Jessie confessed to the audience at an intimate London gig days ago that she was "frightened" because she felt so exposed on stage.

It is not known how the fan managed to break her leg. A spokesman for the star refused to comment on the incident last night.

But a source said: "Now Jessie's on The Voice and getting bigger and bigger, she knows it is time to review security and the risks to her.

"She loves her fans but these things are unavoidable in this day and age. It happens to all pop stars as they become bigger. It's one of the downfalls of fame. Jessie would prefer it wasn't this way."

Jessie will suffer arthritis for life after broke her foot in a stage fall.

She finally had the cast removed last October, but said she would never be able to wear high heels without pain again.

a.tinney@the-sun.co.uk

article.caption: Voice sounds familiar  BBC show packed with recycled faces

caption.#: Jessie J-ust dyed her hair again

article.caption: Jessie J: I'm all about The Voice
The Voice and BGT let viewers judge for themselves
Amanda Holden: Sir Tom could be dead in a week

pages.subdeck: AGONY ... Sergio Aguero
pages.headline: Spray it ain't so!
pages.teaser: MAN CITY hotshot has a seriously blistered foot after a 'stupid' training-ground gaffe
pages.articlebody:
SERGIO AGUERO has a seriously blistered foot after a 'stupid' training-ground blunder that furious Roberto Mancini fears could cost his side the title.

The 25-goal Manchester City striker had a knock that was initially only going to sideline him from last Saturday's game at Stoke.

But a spray on the injury resulted in an allergic reaction, causing the foot to balloon and blister as if it had been burnt.

Aguero, 23, misses today's game with Sunderland and it is unclear for how long he will be out.

Boss Mancini did not want to be drawn on what happened but said: "It is impossible we can lose a player to a stupid situation.

"It is just a stupid injury. It didn't happen at home, it happened here."

With Carlos Tevez still not fit enough to start, Mancini fears the situation could cost them dear.

He said: "For this reason I am really disappointed for what happened."

Mancini wants him fit for next weekend's trip to the Emirates but when asked if it could be a long-term problem the Italian said: "I hope not. To lose our top striker for a stupid thing... I hope he can recover for Arsenal."

article.caption: Top 10 stupid football injuries
Mancini: I don't trust Balotelli  who can?
City would be mad to axe Mancini
Why Mario can't be trusted

POINTING THE FINGER ... Roberto Mancini

pages.subdeck: Victory ... George Galloway
pages.headline: Cat that creamed Labour
pages.teaser: LABOUR leader warned to learn quickly from shock Respect by-election victory
pages.byline: By TOM NEWTON DUNN, Political Editor, and STEPHEN MOYES
pages.articlebody:
ED Miliband was last night warned to learn quickly from George Galloway's shock Respect by-election victory  or face a thrashing at the polls in 2015.

Galloway  ridiculed for his creepy cat impression on Celebrity Big Brother in 2006  snatched Labour's safe seat of Bradford West with a huge 36 per cent swing on Thursday night.

The 57-year-old former pal of Iraq tyrant Saddam Hussein won more than half of all the votes cast  after telling Muslim voters he was more devout than Labour's Muslim candidate.

Gutted Mr Miliband was embarrassingly forced to abandon a long-planned victory visit to the city yesterday. The hapless Labour leader admitted it was "an incredibly disappointing result".

Seeking to calm party anger, he vowed: "I'm going to go back to the constituency in the coming weeks to talk to people there about why this result happened."

But critics were furious at the ballot-box battering, which came despite a ten-point opinion poll lead and after David Cameron's worst week in power.

Ex-Labour Home Secretary David Blunkett told The Sun: "The inquest will throw up a number of lessons that must be taken on board now, not in three years' time. We fail to learn them at our peril."

He added: "It's astonishing anyone could cast a vote for someone who has gone on Big Brother and got down on his hands and knees to lick milk like a cat.

"Is our political system letting people down so badly they'll vote for any buffoon?"

With local and London mayor elections just over a month away on May 3, another senior party figure, who didn't want to be named, said: "Bradford West is a wake-up call for Red Ed. He needs to change tack and show the party he can deliver in elections."

Labour campaign chiefs also came under fire. Labour MP John Mann fumed: "We had no game plan, no strategy. But what was particularly disconcerting was having no Muslim doorknockers, no Urdu speaker, no hijab-wearing woman talking to Muslim women voters."

Senior Labour sources blamed "local factors"  but refused to say whether that meant ethnic issues or dirty campaigning.

Tory co-chairman Baroness Warsi also waded in to the row, saying the result cast a shadow over Labour's chances at the next election.

She said: "This tells you everything you need to know about Ed Miliband's weak leadership."

The Tory vote was also badly slashed in Bradford West  while the Lib Dems got so few votes they lost their £500 deposit.

Galloway boasted it was "the most sensational victory in British political history".

He said: "This is the Bradford Spring, just like the Cairo Spring and the Tunisian Spring."

But there were fears it would split Bradford's mixed community along ethnic lines.

Protester Thomas Johnson, 26, pelted eggs at the newly elected MP as he toured Bradford yesterday, sparking a scuffle. Mr Johnson shouted: "He's a sycophant, a parasite on this city." But Galloway crowed: "He didn't get me."

Galloway won despite hardly ever setting foot in Bradford West. It came after the Catholic-born Scot wrote to all Muslim voters  claiming to be more religious that his "moderate Muslim" Labour rival. He poured doubt on the faith of barrister Imran Hussain, 33, by suggesting he drinks alcohol.

Galloway also astonishingly claimed to have saved the people of Palestine and Iraq, and to be single-handedly fighting to free those of Afghanistan and Iran. The anti-war veteran, standing for the left-wing Respect Party, wrote: "You should vote for him because he is a 'Muslim', they say, and because he is of Pakistani background... God knows who is a Muslim. And he knows who is not. Instinctively, so do you."

In the same letter he claimed: "I, George Galloway, do not drink alcohol and never have.

"Ask yourself if the other candidate in this election can say that." He said he had been given "Pakistan's highest civil awards for services to democracy and for my work for the freedom of Kashmir". There was no mention of his visit to Saddam Hussein when he told the despot: "Sir, I salute your courage, your strength, your indefatigability."

Nor did he talk of pretending to be a cat licking milk from actress Rula Lenska's hands in Big Brother. He claimed his letter was a response to the Labour campaign, "which consisted of a claim that people should vote for him because he was a Pakistani Muslim".

The by-election was sparked after Labour's Marsha Singh stepped down due to ill health. It was the second time Galloway snatched a seat from Labour, which expelled him in 2003.

He won in Bethnal Green and Bow in 2005  but then lost to Labour in Limehouse and Poplar in 2010.

t.newtondunn@the-sun.co.uk



myView

By TOM NEWTON DUNN Political Editor

GEORGE Galloway's victory stopped Ed Miliband's revival in its tracks yesterday, like a .45 calibre bullet.

The rookie Labour leader was viewed by Westminster as having finally turned a corner in the last two weeks.

Some decent Despatch Box performances capitalising on Cameron and Osborne's shambolic collapse gave him a golden opportunity to be heard. Bradford West may have ended that for good.

The worst thing for Labour about the jumbo drubbing is that its arrogant campaign chiefs had no clue it was coming  even as the polls closed on Thursday, Ed's aides were bragging to journalists about a comfortable win.

The party's ten-point lead in the polls is revealed to be as soft as French cheese.

There is a lesson today too for the Tories. As long as the bungling PM and his ministers are even more unpopular than Ed, they look extremely silly when they gloat.



myView

By ANILA BAIG in Bradford

GEORGE Galloway's victory has been described as a shock.

But looking around the constituency in which I live, the writing  on posters, hoardings and banners  was on the wall. And on cars, lampposts and any other surface, for that matter.

In Manningham, in the heart of Bradford, there was jubilation and not just because of Friday prayers. Young and old talked of "a breath of fresh air" and "a new voice". Taxi drivers beeped their horns, shouting: "Respect! Respect!"

My phone was full of texts from 40-something friends calling his victory "historic". One sounded hysterical, claiming it was a huge honour that Gorgeous George chose to stand here.

"It's a turning point for Bradford, change is coming!" she declared. She's not the only giddy one. At one house with a George poster in the window I was embraced by Maqsood Bi, 66, who said: "He came and talked to us. I decided there and then I trusted him. We did vote Labour but we like his party. We support the people of Palestine and he helps people in trouble."

Galloway fashioned himself to look "Muslim". On Twitter he spoke of "God willing" and on banners, against a green backdrop  associated with Muslim countries  he is bearded and his balding pate looks like an Islamic skullcap.

But voters don't care whether he is Muslim or not. Law student Raja Tuqeer, 20, said: "He was speaking a lot of sense."

The general feeling seems to be that Galloway ran rings round Imran Hussein and was more eloquent. No one seemed to even know who the Tory candidate was.

Posing with his car, festooned in Galloway posters, Raja said: "We celebrated at his office. There were 1,500 people there at 3am and most were 18 to 25. I wasn't interested in politics before but this feels right."

Married Samsor and Elena Safi did not vote and were wary of Galloway's motives. He said: "I'm Muslim and feel he only speaks for Muslims. He should stand for every person. The city is so divided, we need someone to bring us together, not just appeal to one part." Mum-of-two Elena said: "I still associate him with Celebrity Big Brother. I can't take him seriously."

In leafy suburb Heaton, opinions ranged from "charismatic and charming" to "an insufferable p****." In working-class Allerton High Street, Stanley Profit, 85, said: "I find him very boastful."

Children's centre worker Sue Dyde, 53, who picked up a Respect postcard, said: "It's very well thought out. It shows where to put your cross to help anyone who doesn't speak English.

"There's nothing I disagree with, I'm anti-war and want tuition fees axed. People are sick of self-serving politicians. He'll stick up for people."

Galloway was roundly mocked for his Big Brother stint when he pretended to be a cat eating out of Rula Lenska's hands. I hate to say it but for the moment at least, most people in Bradford appearing to be eating out of his.

article.caption: Labour KOd by George Galloway

video.caption: RESPECT politician inflicts a humiliating defeat on Labour in Bradford West seat

image.caption: Victory ... George Galloway

pages.subdeck: Delighted ... Robbie and Ayda
pages.headline: Robbie Williams to be a dad
pages.teaser: STAR says: "Me and Ayda are going to be mummy and daddy this year. We had sex! It works!"
pages.articlebody:
TAKE That star Robbie Williams has announced he is going to be a dad for the first time.

The 38-year-old singer took to his official blog this morning to reveal his wife Ayda Field is expecting.

He wrote: "I've been keeping a secret from you all... Me and Ayda are going to be mummy and daddy this year.

"We had sex! It works!"

The Angels singer admits he and his actress partner have turned into emotional wrecks while preparing for the arrival of their firstborn.

He added: "We've seen scans and cried... Looked at babies in commercials and teared up.

"The nursery is already planned. Basically I'm in love with a little person growing in mummy's belly and can't wait to be a daddy...

"Crying now. Much love much joy. Roberto, mum and little bump. XXXXXX."

image.caption: Delighted ... Robbie and Ayda

nibs.headline: 18 days left to boot Qatada
nibs.teaser: RESTRICTIONS on terror suspect are set to expire
nibs.byline: By GRAEME WILSON, Deputy Political Editor
nibs.articlebody:
HOME Secretary Theresa May has just 18 DAYS to get a deal to boot Abu Qatada out of Britain before tough restrictions on the terror suspect are scrapped.

Home Office chiefs have set up a base in Jordan to try to finalise a deal to send the hate preacher back.

It comes as Sun readers continue to sign our Must Try Harder To Kick Out Qatada petition, with the total now at 122,000. Qatada was freed from jail last month and put on a 22 hours-a-day curfew. He is banned from using the internet and must wear an electronic tag.

His lawyers can to ask for the controls to be ditched on April 17  three months after the European Court of Human Rights stopped Britain deporting him.

The European judges said he could not be sent back unless Jordan promised no evidence used against him had been extracted by torturing other extremists. Jordan has recently changed its constitution to make clear that torture evidence cannot be used in court.

The Home Office is trying to get extra guarantees on how this pledge will be enforced.

Ministers want a water-tight deal on Qatada to ensure it does not get thrown out in court.

"It's complicated and it's frustrating but we're making progress," said one insider last night.

The Special Immigration Appeals Commission must approve any new bid to deport Qatada. If the tribunal accepts Jordan's guarantees, the Home Office will ask for the extremist to be jailed until deportation.

g.wilson@the-sun.co.uk

article.caption: A bigger home for Qatada
'Abu Qatada's exit could backfire'
Exile hate preacher's web rants
Give terror suspects MORE human rights
May tries harder to kick out Qatada

nibs.headline: Drought fear for 35million in Britain
nibs.teaser: RAINFALL, soil moisture and river levels show UK is drier than at any time since 1976
nibs.articlebody:
NEARLY 35million Brits will soon be officially in drought, figures revealed yesterday.

Maps of recent rainfall, soil moisture and river levels show the UK is drier than at any time since 1976.

The South West and West Midlands are at risk of being declared drought areas, the Environment Agency warned. They would join parts of the South East, East Anglia, and South and East Yorkshire already in drought.

The agency said a sizzling week has left two-thirds of rivers "exceptionally low" with decreasing flows, while most reservoirs are below normal levels. It released a shocking new map for March 21-27, with almost all England and Wales in red  symbolising 0 to 1mm of rainfall. Only the South West is a different colour  and even that had just 1mm of rain.

Hosepipe bans hit 22million in the South and East on Thursday  and the agency said a ban on taking water for crops looms for farmers in East Anglia. National drought coordinator Helen Vale said: "We expect water companies to do more to tackle leaks."

article.caption: Hotlines to grass up hose ban cheats
Millions to face hosepipe ban
Drought to spark shortage of potatoes
Drought hits the price of a pint

image.caption: Red peril ... the rain map

nibs.headline: Spy in bag DNA bungle
nibs.teaser: BLUNDER over sample has dashed a key line of inquiry in the 'spy in the bag' mystery
nibs.articlebody:
A BLUNDER over DNA has dashed a key line of inquiry in the "spy in the bag" mystery, it emerged yesterday.

Cops spent 18 months trying to find out who a partial sample found on MI6 code-breaker Gareth Williams' body belonged to.

But hopes of a breakthrough were wrecked when it was discovered the profile was that of a police scientist involved in the original investigation.

The bungle was revealed yesterday at a pre-inquest review into the bizarre death of Mr Williams, 32, whose body was found inside a holdall in 2010. The hearing was told it stemmed from a typing error made by a scientist working for forensic testing lab LGC.

The scientist mistyped the DNA code while writing an email asking for a check.

As a result detectives wasted 18 months looking for a potential suspect who did not exist.

In fact the sample, found on one of Mr Williams' hands, had come from a Metropolitan Police expert who was at his flat in Pimlico, Central London. LGC apologised to Mr Williams' family saying: "We are sorry for any pain this has caused."

Despite extensive tests, police have been unable to say exactly how Mr Williams died.

Coroner Dr Fiona Wilcox expressed "extreme concern" about the DNA bungle.

Lawyer Anthony O'Toole, for Mr Williams' family, claimed spooks involved in the "dark arts of the secret services" may have been responsible for his death or covered it up.

He said a "third party" may have been present in the flat. The inquest is due to begin next month.

m.sullivan@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Riddle ... Gareth Williams

pages.subdeck: Smile ... Anni Dewani with husband Shrien
pages.headline: Joy at hotel...then murder
pages.teaser: NEW bride beams in CCTV image as she saunters along corridor with husband Shrien
pages.articlebody:
NEW bride Anni Dewani beams as she saunters along a corridor with husband Shrien  just hours before her horrific carjack murder.

The CCTV image, which has just been released, was taken in the couple's Cape Town hotel. It shows the casually-dressed pair, with Shrien carrying newspapers and a book, on the morning of the killing.

A later picture shows the couple at 6.17pm  dressed for their fateful night out. Shortly afterwards they pose with arms around each other for a snap in the hotel bar.

But within four hours their taxi was hijacked by two gunmen  who drove off and shot Anni dead.

image.caption: Smile ... Anni Dewani with husband Shrien

pages.subdeck: Feeling lucky? ... a man checks his Mega Millions ticket in New Jersey
pages.headline: £400m: Largest lottery jackpot in history won
pages.teaser: MASSIVE sum will be paid out after no one got all Mega Millions numbers 18 times
pages.articlebody:
THE world's biggest ever lottery jackpot has finally been won potentially making someone richer than Tiger Woods.

Lotto fever gripped the United States ahead of the draw after nobody won the growing pot of cash on 18 successive occasions.

One winning Mega Millions lottery ticket was bought in Maryland but there could be more, organisers say.

Players were estimated to have spent more than $1.5BILLION - or £937million - trying to win the jackpot, which finally fell to numbers 2, 4, 23, 38 and 46, with Mega Ball 23.

If won by a single ticket holder it would be the biggest lottery jackpot win the world has ever seen.

The lucky ticketholder will have beaten odds of 176,000,000 to one and find themselves instantly richer than megastars Mariah Carey and Tiger Woods.

The previous record was set at $390million - £243million - split by two winners in 2007 who bought tickets in Georgia and New Jersey.

The jackpot had surged in the run-up to the draw - soaring from $540million on Thursday during a frenzied buying spree.

Maryland Lottery spokeswoman Carole Everett said: "We're thrilled. We're due and excited."

The prize had been accumulating since January 24 when the numbers were drawn in Atlanta last night.

The winner or winners won't necessarily get the windfall all in one go.

They could choose between 26 annual payments to net the lot or choose instead an upfront sum meaning they lose out $178million.

image.caption: Feeling lucky? ... a man checks his Mega Millions ticket in New Jersey
Huge draw ... there had been enormous queues to buy tickets all over the US

pages.subdeck: Sun ... campaign for VAT U-turn
pages.headline: Cornish patsy
pages.teaser: EUROPEAN Court of Justice ruling meant he was under pressure to add VAT
pages.articlebody:
CHANCELLOR George Osborne was yesterday accused of crumbling to euro judges by enforcing the hated Pasty Tax.

A European Court of Justice ruling meant he was under pressure to either slap VAT on all hot takeaway food or axe the duty completely.

In the case, a German won a bid to carry on selling grilled sausages without charging VAT.

Last night the Treasury admitted they had taken account of a number of court cases. Some Tory bigwigs reckon Mr Osborne will do a U-turn  a call made by The Sun's Who VAT All the Pies? campaign.

Join the nation's crusade against the Pasty Tax by signing the petition below...

Petrol-gaffe minister Frances Maude caused more uproar yesterday by branding Cornish Pasties "starchy". And it emerged that forgetful PM David Cameron had a Greggs sausage roll in January while touring the baker's HQ.



Why fury on pasty's not pie in sky

By DAVID SKELTON, Policy Exchange Deputy Director

THE "Pastygate" story could be written off as a bit of Westminster silliness.

But commentators who say there are more important things to discuss than the price of pies are missing the point.

Dismissing it as trivial shows how out of touch many in Westminster are.

And I'm not just saying that because I'm a North-Easterner proud of the success of a great North-East company like Greggs.

Apart from pasties, the big story this week was that real household income experienced its biggest annual fall for 35 years.

Many people are being squeezed by stagnating wages, rising bills and real worries about job security  and they don't feel politicians really understand or relate to their problems.

Many people are struggling to keep their heads above water and seeing the cost of their lunchtime pasty rise by a fifth will have a real impact on their everyday budget.

A poll this week showed three-quarters of the "strivers"  the skilled working class who helped Thatcher and Blair into Downing Street  believe the Tories stand for the rich, rather than ordinary people.

And it isn't just the Tories who have a problem. Ed Miliband looked awkward and out of place in the photo-shoot in Greggs last week.

Labour need to work harder to reconnect with strivers and those on modest incomes after their vote plummeted at the election.

article.caption: From peasants to pasties... why we've always fought over food
Flying start for Save Our Savouries petition
The pied paupers
Half-baked
Sun's on a roll at Treasury
Let them eat cold pasty

pages.subdeck: Not shining anymore ... Jessica Tregidgo (right) and Lauren Osgood enjoying the recent warm weather at Fistral beach in Newquay, Cornwall
pages.headline: Cool Britannia is back after hot Spring vanishes
pages.teaser: FORECASTERS warn of plunging Spring temps and snow as early sun vanishes
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN went from sizzling to shivering today as temperatures across the UK collapsed.

The spectacular turnaround comes after a record-breaking warm spell earlier this week which saw the country hotter than the Sahara.

Now up to four inches of SNOW could hit northern England and Scotland on Monday. And by Wednesday it could be falling as far south as Lincolnshire, according to the Met Office.

Sleet could also sweep into Kent before a sub-zero night on Tuesday sees thermometers down to -11C (12F) in places.

It's a massive 35C change back into winter, days after Brits had a taste of summer and hopped into their bikinis and deck chairs.

Durham was the hottest spot in the UK yesterday at 19.7C - warmer than normal 18.1C peak of JUNE.

But today it had fallen to just 7C marking a miserable start to the Easter school holidays.

The Met Office warned bitter Arctic winds will bring snow and sleet to higher ground in northern England, Wales and Scotland this week.

While the place that broke records with its steamy temperatures last week is set to become one of the coldest.

Aboyne in Aberdeenshire soared to 23.6C on Tuesday and 18C on Friday - but managed just 7C today.

By Tuesday it will be down to ZERO there with an icy -11C predicted overnight.

Moira Milne, owner of Aboyne's Glendavan House guest house, said: "It seems we're often either hottest or coldest here. It was like mid-summer earlier in the week."

Weather Channel meteorologist Leon Brown said: "Arctic air will reach Scotland on Monday, with 5-10cm of snow over the Highlands and a covering possible at low levels, and 5-8cm of snow over the Pennines and 1cm at lower levels by Tuesday morning.

"The cold front then moves south across the Midlands, Wales and southern England during Tuesday, with some sleet over high ground, with the Chilterns and Downs at risk."

article.caption: It's hot, hot, hot (again) Britain

caption.#: Britain hotter than Bermuda

article.caption: UK temperature record broken - and it's good news for the weekend too

pages.subdeck: Shark victim ... Peter Kurmann
pages.headline: Dad savaged to death by shark
pages.teaser: DEATH of Peter Kurmann, 33, sparks bid to hunt down predator as beach closes
pages.articlebody:
A DAD on a diving trip has been killed by a shark in the deadliest waters on Earth for such attacks.

The beast was being hunted today after father-of-two Peter Kurmann, 33, was savaged while enjoying an early morning dive with his brother.

His is the fourth fatal shark attack off Western Australia in six months and experts are already blaming a Great White.

The shark struck off Stratham Beach in Geographe Bay, south of Perth, last night.

Mr Kurmann's brother escaped uninjured and brought his body back to shore.

Gian said later: "Our family has lost a son, a brother, a husband and a wonderful father.

"'Today our family has suffered a terrible loss. Words cannot express how we feel at this time."

Western Australia was rated the deadliest place on Earth for fatal shark attacks after three men were killed off the state's coast in two months.

Last September body-boarder Kyle Burden, 21, was killed by a shark near Bunker Bay.

The following month Bryn Martin, 64, was savaged while swimming at Cottesloe Beach.

Later the same month Texan George Wainwright, 32, was slaughtered by a Great White while diving at Rottnest Island.

Then in January this year tour operator David Pickering survived an attack by a tiger shark while snorkelling off Coral Bay.

The Western Australia Department of Fisheries is hunting the shark with patrols on the water and in the air.

Manager Tony Cappelluti said: "The surviving brother has said he saw a large shark-like shape of around about four metres (13ft).

"We don't know if he witnessed the attack. There was a boat not far from them and they came and provided assistance when called to.

"They didn't see a shark and there have been no further sightings of a shark so there is no description of the species. We don't know what the species is."

The beach will remain closed this weekend.

The businessman from Vasse near Busselton, close to the scene of the attack, leaves wife Debra and two young sons.

article.caption: Honeymoon widow Gemma relives horror of shark attack
Shark attack surfer saved his own life by riding wave to safety

caption.#: Seal's escape is jaws-dropping

image.caption: Shark victim ... Peter Kurmann

pages.subdeck: Probe ... terraced house in Porthmadog where woman and child were found dead
pages.headline: Mum and son, 3, found dead
pages.teaser: SUSPECT arrested after pair were declared dead at terraced house
pages.articlebody:
A MAN has been arrested on suspicion of murder after a woman and her young son were found dead at a house last night.

The pair were discovered at a terraced home near Porthmadog, Gwynedd around 9.20pm. North Wales Police held a man in his 40s.

Friends and neighbours said the dead woman was mother of three Suzanne Jones - believed to be 40 - and her three-year-old son William. She was said to have two daughters, named as Antonia and Amy.

Retured factory worker Arthur Edwards, 76, who lives two doors from their house, said: "They kept themselves to themselves, as people do nowadays.

"I only fully found out what happened at 8.30 this morning when I received a text message and came out and asked."

David Thomas, 66, from the nearby village of Penmorfa, said he had known Mrs Jones all her life. He added: "Susi was born in this house here and she was a lovely girl who fitted into the community.

"You could not wish for a better full-time mother with the children."

The family were today being comforted by specialist police officers while colleagues checked the house.

A force spokesman said: "Shortly after 9.20pm on Friday March 30, North Wales Police were called to an address in Glanmorfa Terrace, Porthmadog where they discovered an adult female and child who were subsequently declared deceased at the scene."

Detectives are appealing for witnesses or anyone in the street at the time.

Friends and neighbours laid flowers outside the house.

One bouquet carried a handwritten tribute which read: "You were just young your baby to (sic).

"It saddens us your family to (sic). For you both it's been so short, so lives must go on regardlessly (sic)."

video.caption: MAN arrested on suspicion of murder after woman and child found dead in Wales

image.caption: Probe ... terraced house in Porthmadog where woman and child were found dead

pages.subdeck: (Sausage) Roll of honour ... Sam, Greggs boss Ken McMeikan, Sun man Steve Hawkes and Lacey
pages.headline: Flying start for Save Our Savouries petition
pages.teaser: THOUSANDS sign up to bash the Pasty Tax as petition goes nationwide... SIGN IT HERE
pages.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of Brits have signed up to bash the Pasty Tax  as the Sun-backed Save Our Savouries petition went nationwide.

Our lovely Page 3 Girls Sam and Lacey joined Greggs boss Ken McMeikan in Cheapside, London, yesterday for the opening of the bakery chain's 200th London store.

They watched him add his name to the growing list of Pasty Tax protesters.

Within hours, 500 visitors to the City store had followed his example.

Greggs have 1,500 stores across the country so if the sign-up figure is consistent, it means the petition could already have as many as 750,000 signatures.

Britain's bakers plan to march on Downing Street once the petition has more than 100,000 names, so the PM can expect them soon.

Join the nation's crusade against the Pasty Tax by signing the petition below...



They are urging the Chancellor to drop his plan to whack 20 per cent VAT on warm pies, pasties and sausage rolls from October.

Bakers claim it will push many of them to the wall and mean price hikes for punters. One worker, Gary Paddison said: "It's ridiculous.

"We've never had VAT on them before, why change it now? It's just a way for the taxman to collect more money."

Neil Court-Johnson, new owner of Wigan firm Poole's Pies agreed: "It's bonkers."

Greggs chief Mr McMeikan said he had been astounded by public reaction to George Osborne's half-baked tax raid.

The story has gone global too, with the media in Sydney and New York reporting the issue.

The row erupted after The Sun revealed that while pasties are being clobbered with VAT at 20 per cent, CAVIAR escaped the levy.

Mr McMeikan said: "The Sun has been incredible.

"I really want to thank your readers for their support."

One reader, Joybelle, yesterday said: "This really shows that the rich and powerful, including our Prime Minister and Chancellor, haven't got a clue to what real life is at the bottom of the ladder."

article.caption: The pied paupers
Half-baked
Let them eat cold pasty
Pasty tax gets a pasting
From peasants to pasties... why we've always fought over food
Cornish patsy

image.caption: (Sausage) Roll of honour ... Sam, Greggs boss Ken McMeikan, Sun man Steve Hawkes and Lacey

pages.subdeck: Legs 11 at No10 ... David Walliams and his wife Lara Stone
pages.headline: Walliams and wife visit No10
pages.teaser: FUNNYMAN'S supermodel wife sets pulses racing at Downing Street in mini-dress
pages.articlebody:
TV funnyman David Walliams visits Downing Street yesterday with sexy supermodel wife Lara Stone  who livened up the corridors of power in a tiny mini-dress.

Marathon swimmer Walliams was among Sport Relief stars invited for tea with the PM at No10.

Blue Peter's Helen Skelton, comedian John Bishop and ex-rugby ace Josh Lewsey also attended after their sporting feats for charity.

Walliams, 40, and Lara, 28, chatted to David Cameron about last year's heroic Thames swim, which left the comic ill for weeks.

The PM said: "You swam through my constituency."

Fortunately, the star, 40, showed more restraint in Mr Cameron's company than his camp Little Britain character Sebastian, who tries to steal hugs off the fictional PM.

pages.subdeck: Animal cruelty ... dogs
pages.headline: Pair kept 56 dogs in semi
pages.teaser: RSPCA inspectors 'swamped by sea of dogs' in living room & 'too many to count' in garden
pages.articlebody:
THESE are some of the 56 large dogs a couple kept crammed in their "dirty" four-bed semi.

RSPCA inspectors were "swamped by a sea of dogs" in the living room and "too many to count" in the garden of their home.

The pets included huskies, German shepherds and rottweilers. There were also three cats in the bathroom, six birds in cages and four chinchillas  69 animals in all.

James Hood, 40, and his wife Nicola, 31, of Minehead, Somerset,  who have five children  admitted nine animal cruelty charges at Taunton Magistrates' Court. They will be sentenced next month.

pages.subdeck: Fun ... camel at Coleen Rooney's party in Cheshire
pages.headline: A camel at Coleen's do
pages.teaser: WAG stages an Arabian Nights-themed party to mark her turning 26 next week
pages.articlebody:
PARTY girl Coleen Rooney had an Arabian Nights-themed birthday bash last night  complete with a camel.

Family and friends joined in the fun to mark her 26th next Tuesday.

Guests turned up dressed as Arabian royalty, belly dancers and even one as a Sultan.

Friends of Coleen and her Manchester United star hubby Wayne, 26, clambered on to the camel, called Alice, to take a ride around the couple's huge garden.

One onlooker said: "All the guests were dressed head to toe in amazing bright-coloured Arabian costumes with head dresses on."

There was a mild disturbance about noise as party hits like Stevie Wonder's Sir Duke played at the couple's Cheshire mansion.

One neighbour approached security guards at the home at 10.30pm and said: "I can't hear my television."

Earlier it emerged that Coleen is hot for a new hobby  Bikram yoga, which is practised in 105°F (40°C) heat.

She wrote online: "It's hard but you feel great afterwards. I was bright red and sweating."

caption.#: Kai one get Wayne free
Wayne Rooney's

pages.subdeck: The law ... cops deal with riots
pages.headline: Met suspends 'racist cop' over 'n***** insult' during riots
pages.teaser: SUSPECT recorded officer's abuse during arrest which saw him 'strangled', it is claimed
pages.articlebody:
A COP has been suspended over claims he called a man a 'n*****' during last year's London riots.

The officer, named by sources as Met officer PC Alex MacFarlane, was allegedly recorded by the suspect on his mobile phone as he was taken into custody.

The officer was said to have told the 21-year-old black man: "The problem with you is you will always be a n*****, yeah?

"That's your problem, yeah."

The Independent Police Complaints Commission investigated and passed a file to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) which decided not to press charges against the officer or two colleagues.

But last night officials said they would look again at the case after the man's lawyers complained.

Grace Ononiwu, deputy chief crown prosecutor for the CPS London, said: "Lawyers for the complainant have written to the CPS and asked us to review our decision.

"I have considered the matter personally and directed that all of the evidence should be reconsidered and a fresh decision taken by a senior lawyer with no previous involvement in this matter.

"That process will be completed as soon as possible and is the procedure we often adopt when pre-action protocol judicial review proceedings are initiated."

According to the Guardian, the officer on the tape also told the suspect: "You'll always have black skin colour.

"Don't hide behind your colour, yeah. Be proud. Be proud of who you are, yeah. Don't hide behind your black skin."

Another officer allegedly used other foul language and admitted strangling him.

Near the end of the recording  posted online - the man can be heard saying: "I get this all the time."

He then tells the officer: "Make sure you do a lot with your sixty grand, 'cos you're not going to get it no more, bruv."

"We'll definitely speak again about this. It's gonna go all the way, it's gonna go all the way - remember."

A Scotland Yard spokesman said: "We can confirm that the MPS received a complaint alleging a man arrested on August 11 2011 was subjected to discriminatory behaviour (racial remarks); assault and oppressive conduct/or harassment.

"These are serious allegations. Any use of racist language or excessive use of force is not acceptable.

"The MPS's Directorate of Professional Standards referred this case to the IPCC who are independently investigating.

"Following the alleged incident, three officers were the subject of a misconduct investigation. One of the officers has been suspended in relation to this matter pending the result of the IPCC investigation.

"One of the officers has been placed on restricted duties on an unrelated matter and another remains on full duties."

article.caption: Riots blamed on poor parenting
Harry Potter actor gets two years for riot gang violence

image.caption: The law ... cops deal with riots

pages.subdeck: Fire ... Azamara Quest
pages.headline: 100 Brits aboard fire-hit liner
pages.teaser: BRITONS are among 1,000 people on board the fire-hit liner Azamara Quest in Far East, limping back to land
pages.articlebody:
ONE hundred Britons were adrift on a cruise ship last night after a fire on board crippled the luxury liner.

The blaze in the engine room of the 30,000-ton Azamara Quest - with 600 tourists and 411 crew aboard - knocked out power.

The captain advised passengers to leave their cabins and muster at emergency assembly points. No injuries among guests were reported but five crew members suffered smoke inhalation and one was more seriously injured.

The fire was quickly extinguished but the ship was left running on back-up generators.

Engineers today managed to restore enough power to get the giant vessel moving again and it was later heading at up to six knots towards a Malaysian port were the cruise will end earlier than scheduled.

The 100 Brits on board were reported to be displaying a bit of "Dunkirk spirit".

Valerie and Billy Scott called son Jeremy from the ship to tell him they are "fine".

Jeremy said: "There is no panic, everybody is fine and they are just getting on with it.

"It is the Dunkirk spirit and they are making the best of the situation."

Valerie, 70, and Billy, 71, were on their 60th cruise.

Air conditioning, running water and refrigeration were restored after the engine was brought back into operation.

A statement from ship owners Azamara Club Cruises said: "Engineers on board Azamara Quest have been able to restore propulsion to the ship.

"Azamara Quest is currently sailing directly to Sandakan, Sabah, Malaysia at between three to six knots.

"Based on this speed, the ship is expected to arrive in Sandakan within 24 to 48 hours."

The damage caused by the fire means the rest of the cruise will be cancelled once the ship has docked.

The 12-year-old vessel was crippled in the first week of a 17-night cruise round the Far East costing around £2,500 a head, starting from Hong Kong and due to finish in Singapore on April 12.

The ship is owned by Royal Caribbean Cruises based in Miami Azamara Club Cruises. Its CEO Larry Pimentel is set to fly to Sandakan to meet passengers.

A spokesman said: "Until then, we will be working with our guests to determine how we can best assist them with next steps and travel arrangements."

Two coastguard vessels and a patrol boat were expected to reach the liner today.

It comes only weeks after at least 30 passengers and crew died in the Costa Concordia disaster off Italy. Its sister ship the Costa Allegra later had an engine room fire in the Indian Ocean.

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: "We are aware of an incident on board the Azamara Quest and are in contact with the Philippines Coast Guard and Royal Caribbean International cruises.

"A consular team from the region will be sent to meet the ship when it docks to see what consular assistance we can provide."

People concerned about friends or family should go to the Azamara Quest Facebook page, the Azamara Quest website or contact the Azamara Quest helpline on 001 408 916 9001.

article.caption: Costa crash captain was not wearing his glasses
Costa Allegra Brits 'ate salami sarnies for 3 days'

image.caption: Fire ... Azamara Quest

pages.subdeck: Family planning ... Osama Bin Laden
pages.headline: Osama's kids while on run
pages.teaser: TWO of the terror chief's children were even born in a STATE HOSPITAL in Pakistan
pages.articlebody:
OSAMA Bin Laden's youngest wife has revealed they had FOUR children together while he was on the run as the world's most wanted terrorist.

Two of them were even born in a state hospital in Pakistan  where the al-Qaeda chief fled just months after 9/11.

Amal Abdulfattah, 29, said the family moved around the country several times before settling in Abbottabad, where Bin Laden was shot dead in a raid by US Navy Seals in May last year. Yemen-born Amal, who was shot in the leg during the raid, said she offered herself to Bin Laden in 2000 because she wanted to be married to a "holy warrior".

She lived with his two other wives at the al-Qaeda HQ in Kandahar, Afghanistan, and there gave birth to first child Saifa.

After the 2001 attacks on the US, Bin Laden hid out in the remote Tora Bora region of Afghanistan while Amal fled to Pakistan. She told investigators: "We all scattered."

Bin Laden crossed into Pakistan in 2002, where he was reunited with his bride in Peshawar.

Amal revealed they also hid out in Swat Valley near the Afghan border in accommodation arranged by Osama's elder son Saad. The pair moved on to Haripur, where she gave birth in the local hospital to daughter Aasia in 2003 and son Ibrahim a year later. In 2005 they switched to nearby Abbottabad, in a high-walled compound.

Another girl Zainab was born in 2006 and a boy Hussain in 2008. Bin Laden's first two wives rejoined him  and, like Amal, were held after he died, aged 54.

Amal refused to say if the family had been in contact with any Pakistani officials while on the run. They want to deport her to Yemen for breaching a three-month visa when she initially arrived in Pakistan 12 years ago.

Bin Laden's two other widows Khairia Hussain Sabir and Siham Sharif and their daughters, who all refuse to speak to investigators, face immigration charges next week.

n.syson@the-sun.co.uk

article.caption: Osama Bin Laden's wives in spat No2
Osama Bin Laden wives pulled apart in catfight
Bin Laden hid terror codes in the Bible
It's Bin demolished
Osama Bin Laydee

image.caption: Family planning ... Osama Bin Laden

pages.subdeck: 'Thanks for support' ... Fabrice Muamba smiles as he sits up in hospital
pages.headline: 1st Muamba pic since heart failed
pages.teaser: THE first picture of a smiling Fabrice Muamba has been posted on the stricken footie ace's Twitter page.
pages.articlebody:
FABRICE Muamba sits up and smiles yesterday as he is snapped in hospital for the first time since his cardiac arrest.

The 24-year-old Bolton Wanderers ace asked fiancee Shauna Magunda to tweet the photo to thank his fans for their "overwhelming support".

Players and supporters have been praying for the dad of one since he collapsed during a televised FA Cup tie at Spurs two weeks ago. He later awoke at the London Chest Hospital.

The Sun launched its Love Heart campaign to teach schoolkids the life-saving CPR used on the stricken player.

JOIN OUR CAMPAIGN FOR CPR IN SCHOOLS BY CLICKING HERE

Jailed Liam Stacey, 21, of Swansea, has lost his appeal against a 56-day term for racist tweets about Muamba.

image.caption: 'Thanks for support' ... Fabrice Muamba smiles as he sits up in hospital

pages.subdeck: Mess ... Linda Parkes' home
pages.headline: Body of compulsive hoarder lost in home full of rubbish
pages.teaser: FIREMEN had to search the woman's home for three days to find the body, inquest hears
pages.articlebody:
FIREMEN had to search a house for three days to find the body of a compulsive hoarder because it was so full of rubbish, an inquest heard yesterday.

Linda Parkes, 59, died from smoke inhalation in a fire which was started when piled-up material fell on to a flame on the cooker hob in the kitchen.

Firefighters arrived at the home in Long Eaton, Derbys, to find piles of waste "from floor to ceiling" with the mess in the kitchen around 5ft deep.

Fire brigade manager David Paul told the Derby inquest: "We had to crawl through the top of doorways to get into the rooms. In the kitchen the mess was about 5ft. There were rubbish bags, rotting floors and rodent droppings."

Coroner Paul McCandless recorded a verdict of death by misadventure.

He said he would write to the Government to ask for council officials to be allowed to enter the homes of excessive hoarders if they feared a fire risk.

image.caption: Mess ... Linda Parkes' home

pages.subdeck: Alert ... air ambulance
pages.headline: Boy, 3, injured in window fall
pages.teaser: TODDLER suffers severe head injuries and is airlifted to hospital by helicopter where his condition is stable
pages.byline: By ANTHONY FRANCE and ALEX WEST
pages.articlebody:
A BOY of three suffered severe head injuries in a 15ft-plunge from an open window.

The toddler, who fell on to concrete, was airlifted to hospital by helicopter. His condition was stable last night as cops launched a probe into the mystery fall.

Police were unable to say where the boy's parents were when he fell, just after noon.

Nobody had been arrested but detectives from the Scotland Yard's Child Abuse Investigation Command were looking into the incident on Wednesday at a semi-detached house in Greenwich, South-East London.

A Metropolitan Police spokesman said: "At about 12.28pm police were called by the Ambulance Service regarding a three-year-old boy who had fallen from a first-floor window.

"The child remains in hospital where his condition is described as stable.

"Detectives from the Metropolitan Police Child Abuse Command are making inquiries.

"No arrests have been made."

image.caption: Alert ... air ambulance

pages.subdeck: A BGT hit ... Ashley Elliot
pages.headline: 'One-man, One Direction'
pages.teaser: HARRY Styles welcomes 'new member' of One Direction  a 16-year-old BGT wannabe
pages.articlebody:
HARRY STYLES has welcomed a new member of One Direction  a 16-year-old Britain's Got Talent wannabe.

Musician Ashley Elliot is shown auditioning for BGT this weekend.

It prompts funnyman judge David Walliams to quip to his fellow judge: "Simon, he's like a xylophone-playing, one-man One Direction!"

So later, on ITV2's spin-off show, host Stephen Mulhern puts in a call to teenage heart-throb Harry and asks him if Ashley can join the band.

He says: "Just a quickie, do you need a xylophone player for the group?"

And Harry jokes back: "Do you know what, we were actually having this exact conversation the other day. We think that's the problem, the missing link."

The prank will be shown this weekend on Britain's Got More Talent.

  • BGT's David Walliams is back on the BBC too  starring alongside Jennifer Saunders and Timothy Spall in an adaptation of PG Wodehouse's Blandings.

    Walliams, who will play "The Efficient Baxter", Lord Emsworth's busybody secretary, said: "It's true. I'm very excited to be acting alongside my hero Timothy Spall."

    Last night a source added: "David might be a huge TV personality but he absolutely adores acting.

    "Baxter is the perfect character for him."

    The six-part series has just started filming and will be broadcast in the autumn. David will be in two episodes.

article.caption: Britain's Got Talent star Jonathan Antoine and his red hot duet Stephanie
Meet the BGT babe bringing Cowell out in a Cole sweat
George Sampson wants to be lamped
Britain's Got Talent's Jonathan Antoine's sister is an aspiring model
Only Boys Aloud singer's bum deal

image.caption: A BGT hit ... Ashley Elliot

pages.headline: A cataclysm
pages.teaser: READ The Sun Says leader comment to see our take on pressing issues of the day
pages.articlebody:
NOT a vote has been cast and already the Tories have managed to get taxes down.

Labour's surrender on 10 per cent extra cider duty is a triumph for David Cameron.

The Tories also blocked Labour's planned broadband tax.

Not a bad start as the Tories were clear winners on Day One of the election campaign.

In the Commons, Mr Cameron exposed Gordon Brown's weasel words over Labour's jobs tax.

Mr Brown says the business world has been deceived by the Tories into thinking that Labour's National Insurance tax rise will cost jobs.

Business leaders say Mr Brown is patronising, "economically illiterate" and insults their intelligence.

Almost seventy of Britain's biggest employers  including one of Mr Brown's own advisers  say the Tories are RIGHT.

The Sun agrees. Making firms pay more in tax for every person hired means bosses take on fewer workers.

Only in the warped world of Gordon Brown does raising National Insurance help unemployment.

The fed-up business community has washed its hands of union-run Labour.

Employers think that there will be more REAL jobs under the Tories.

Exactly what the country needs to hear.

Blaze heroes

FIREMEN didn't hesitate when they arrived at a blazing block of high-rise flats.

They plunged straight in  and two tragically lost their lives.

The Sun pays tribute to Hampshire fire heroes James Shears and Alan Bannon.

The brave men and women of our emergency services are very special.

When it comes to the crunch, they lay their lives on the line for us.

We are very lucky. We should be grateful and never forget their sacrifice.

Brave champ

TENNIS ace Martina Navratilova faces another tough challenge.

The legendary champ is diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 53.

Not even a superfit athlete like Martina is safe from a cancer that affects women indiscriminately.

Many Sun readers will have a relative or friend who has been struck down.

Cancer survival rates in Britain have improved over the years. But they lag behind much of Europe and America, where Martina is optimistic about her prospects.

Yes, times are tough. But our next Government must do much more to improve our record on survival rates for breast and other cancers.

Brave Martina, who never gave up on court, will not give up on this fight either.

pages.subdeck: BlackBerry ... lost out to rivals Apple and Google
pages.headline: Black to basics
pages.teaser: GIANT behind Blackberry phones vows to return to basics after plunging into red
pages.articlebody:
THE GIANT behind BLACKBERRY phones has vowed to go back to basics after plunging into the red.

RESEARCH IN MOTION tore up its business blueprint and admitted defeat in the race to rival APPLE and GOOGLE.

New boss Thorsten Heins signalled the company would focus squarely on corporate customers  the mainstay of the Noughties.

Mr Heins said: "We plan to capitalise on our leading position in this segment. BlackBerry cannot succeed if we try to be all things to all people."

Last night RIM insisted this did not mean it was deserting the consumer market altogether. Experts said it was likely to focus on making "two or three category killers".

RIM lost £78million in the three months to March, according to annual results published in the US.

Sales of BlackBerry smartphones dived 21 per cent to 11.1million. BlackBerry's Messenger service has proved a huge hit over the past year  but hardly generates any cash.

Market share figures for the year so far also illustrate BlackBerry's slide. Smartphones using Google's Android operating system account for almost half the market in the US. In the UK, Android's share has gone from 37.8 per cent to 48.5 per cent in the past year. Apple has grown from 22.7 to 28.7 per cent.

In the same period BlackBerry has fallen from 24.4 per cent to 17.1.

Industry insiders said BlackBerry had failed to innovate and meet the rising challenge from its big two rivals.

One expert told The Sun: "They did so well for so long by being the only real phone to offer email for businesses. But others have now caught up."

The launch of the BlackBerry 7 in the coming months will prove critical to the outcome for the year.

Victor Basta, head of mergers and acquisitions advisory firm MAGISTER ADVISORS, said: "The real issue is fundamentally strategic: why should RIM exist when all other smartphone makers are developing better products faster?"



myView



By STEVE HAWKES, Business Editor

LIKE NOKIA, BlackBerry is paying the price for thinking it could do no wrong, for so long  then making stupid mistakes. For instance, in 2010 it launched the Pearl handset and ditched the Qwerty keyboard that customers loved. It will be a long road back.

Capita staff strike plans



UNIONS are threatening a strike at oursourcing specialist CAPITA  over plans to ship hundreds of jobs to India.

Capita told its 4,000 staff in the IT division yesterday that ten per cent had to go to cut costs.

Around 300 of the roles transferred from centres including Reading, Glasgow and Bournemouth will go to Pune on the subcontinent.

The staff work on accounts for insurers PRUDENTIAL, ROYAL LONDON and PHOENIX.

Unite national officer Dave Fleming said: "Capita is a highly profitable company and to treat loyal and highly skilled workers in this way is deplorable."

An insider added: "We knew this was coming. A load of people came over from India recently  they may as well have brought tape measures with them the sizing up they were doing."

Capita  which made £385million last year  insisted that it needed a "revised delivery model" to save money.

  • THE boss of FORD took home nearly $30MILLION (£18.4million) last year after the car giant made its first profit in more than a decade.

    Alan Mulally, left, got a cash bonus of £3.1m plus a £1.2m salary. The rest came from stock options and share awards. US unions called the windfall "outrageous" and "morally wrong".

  • THE former boss of Mr Sheen-to-Nurofen giant RECKITT BENCKISER picked up £12MILLION last year.

    Bart Becht, who quit in September, got £10million from share awards. Reckitt said potential long-term awards to successor Rakesh Kapoor will be cut by a third.

  • THE FTSE 100 ROSE 26.42 TO 5768.45

pages.subdeck: Emergency ... leaking gas at Total's Elgin platform
pages.headline: Rig crisis: Leak seen month ago
pages.teaser: BUT it is not known when Govt was informed as flare threat 'extinguishes itself'
pages.articlebody:
OIL giant TOTAL knew for a MONTH of severe issues at its crisis-hit Elgin rig, it was revealed yesterday.

All 238 workers were evacuated from the North Sea platform last Sunday amid fears of a huge blast  after it was engulfed by a deadly gas cloud.

But yesterday Philippe Guys  boss of the French firm's UK exploration arm  admitted they were aware a capped well was leaking last month.

They made an immediate decision to set about fixing it on February 25  exactly a month before the alert.

But it is not known when the UK Government and outside safety experts were first informed about the problems. Mr Guys told a news conference in Aberdeen: "On February 25 we observed irregular pressure in the annuli (the space between the wellbore and its metal casing deep below the seabed.).

"We very quickly moved to kill the annuli pressure by pumping it full with high density mud. During this process, on March 25, we observed a sudden pressure increase followed by an escape of mud, then gas."

Workers on the platform off Scotland's East Coast said they raised concerns about the well earlier this month  with trade unions claiming the men's fears had been "fobbed off". Details emerged yesterday suggesting it wasn't until March 4 that Total pumped heavy mud into the seabed in a bid to "kill" the well.

Total  whose share price is now at its lowest since December  said the source of the gas leak is a 13,000ft deep reservoir. Nearly 200,000 cubic metres of gas a day is escaping from the base of the platform.

Mr Guys said: "We continue to observe the situation using satellites, surveillance spotter planes three times a day, and maintaining standby vessels in the vicinity of the installation."

Safety concerns were heightened by a flare blazing near the rig. Operators have now confirmed it has finally "extinguished itself".

A statement from the company said: "Total can this morning confirm that the flare on the Elgin platform has extinguished itself.

"We received the first indication that the flare may be out at 12.07 yesterday from our first surveillance flight of the day. The news was then reaffirmed at 16.36 following our second flight of the day.

"We received what we consider final confirmation at 08.20 this morning, when our sea vessels on location reported no further flare activity through the night."

The company had said there was minimal risk from the flare  burning nearly 500ft above sea level.

Choc and pwoar



THE founder of top choc brand GU is lavishing cash on lingerie.

James Averdieck is investing £50,000 in web-based specialist BLUEBELLA. He said: "Both firms deal in pleasure and indulgence."

Gas bills are frozen



SCOTTISH & SOUTHERN ENERGY has vowed to freeze household bills as it prepares to hand £750million to shareholders.

The windfall for investors would be enough to pay the annual gas and electricity bills of 625,000 households.

But SSE insisted its nine million customers would not face higher charges until October "at the earliest".

It said it would be sticking by a price-freeze pledge first made in January.

SSE yesterday signalled it was on course to make profits of £1.3billion for 2011-12. The firm said gas consumption in the past year has plunged 19 per cent, partly due to a mild winter.

  • THE boss of BRITISH GAS picked up a £339,000 bonus last year  despite lower profits at the energy giant. Phil Bentley's award will be paid in shares.

    Details of the payout came two days after British Gas cut 300 jobs in its business division, and transferred the work to Asia.

Brave builders were hoisted to the top to carry out structural work on the beacon yesterday.

The Shard is due to be completed next February.

pages.subdeck: In control ... Tulisa keeps her eyes on Jack O'Connell
pages.headline: Tulisa heads out with Jack
pages.teaser: SEX tape star keeps her eyes firmly on boyfriend Jack O'Connell as they enjoy a late-night date
pages.articlebody:
TULISA keeps her eyes firmly on boyfriend Jack O'Connell as they enjoy a late-night date.

The X Factor judge, who was recently betrayed by an ex who leaked a sex tape of the former couple, kept her attention focused firmly on her new man after they enjoyed cosy dinner at Hakkasan in London.

One would think Skins star Jack, 21, might have had a spot of trouble keeping his eyes on his food too, judging by Tulisa's eye-popping dress.

Tulisa, 23, toasted National Cleavage Day by pouring her ample curves in a revealing red frock.

The N-Dubz singer started going out with the 21-year-old actor earlier this month just days after her fling with The Only Way Is Essex pin-up Mark Wright in Miami.

Earlier this month Tulisa apologised to fans after admitting it WAS her in the sex tape.

Tulisa said: "I am devastated, heartbroken.

"When you share an intimate moment with someone that you love and trust you never imagine for one minute that footage may at any point be shared with the rest of the UK."

The film, from a high-quality camera phone, shows Tulisa performing a sex act for over six minutes.

An internet firm charged viewers £3.90 to download it on Monday but the site was suspended several hours later.

Tulisa split up with her N-Dubz bandmate Richard "Fazer" Rawson, 25, in January after a two-year relationship.

The Girls Aloud beauty clung onto the strapping singer as she tried to keep upright on a cobbled street.

Curvy Kim is rarely out on the London social scene because of her theatre commitments with Shrek, in which she is playing Princess Fiona.

So she dolled herself up to the max for a dinner date with her man of nine years.

While she looked delectable in her nude wedges which matched her silk dress, the heels appeared tricky to manoeuvre in on the uneven pavement outside Gilgamesh restaurant in North London.

Smirking Justin had no such difficulties, keeping casual in black jeans and white trainers.

pages.articlebody:
RIHANNA clearly has a head for heights as she munches her dinner on the window ledge of her hotel room.

While the view would be enough to make most folks' stomach churn, the singer poses for a photo with a pot of noodles in her left hand.

After her brief spell in the UK, the Bajan star has jetted to Japan to continue the promotion of new movie Battleships.

And after a tiring flight, Rihanna couldn't wait to tuck into a tasty snack.

Tweeting the picture of herself posing next to a window, the star said: "She thinkin phillipe I'm thinkin Ramen noodles".

Another shot saw Rihanna take a cheeky snap of herself and her new blonde locks.

She added: "I'm so high up. Not so sunny here."

Rihanna experienced the sizzling temperatures in London this week during several photocalls for Battleships with co-star Brooklyn Decker.

During her stay Rihanna also took the trusty Underground to see pal Drake perform at the O2.

SUPERMODEL Lara Stone has her hand's full as she leaves a restaurant after a date with husband David Walliams.

The Dutch beauty cradled their pet pooch Zimbio as well as a colourful dog toy and her handbag after a fancy fish dinner at Scott's in Mayfair.

While the temperatures dropped a little last night, the couple decided to dine outside on one of the tables on the pavement.

Lara wrapped up warm in a fur jacket and leather trousers #&151; in contrast to the tiny mini dress she wore for her trip to Downing Street yesterday.

The beauty joined marathon swimmer David as he was invited for tea with the PM at No10.

Blue Peter's Helen Skelton, comedian John Bishop and ex-rugby ace Josh Lewsey also attended after their sporting feats for charity.

David, 40, and Lara, 28, chatted to David Cameron about last year's heroic Thames swim, which left the comic ill for weeks.

pages.headline: Russell Brand: I'm well, I don't need to let go
pages.teaser: RUSSELL Brand has insisted he is 'doing well' following his short-lived marriage to Katy Perry
pages.articlebody:
RUSSELL Brand has insisted he is doing 'well' following his short-lived marriage to Katy Perry.

The comic, 36, filed for divorce from Part of Me chart-topper Katie in December, just 14 months after their wedding.

But Brand today revealed he is not bitter.

He said: "I'm well. You don't need to brush it off if you don't get it on you in the first place.

"I don't have to let anything go. I don't hold on to anything negative. It's the same as zero-ness.

"You can't let go of something you don't hold, you know. It's meaningless, and much of our world is predicated on meaninglessness. And I don't do that anymore,"

The Get Him To The Greek actor is now dating Hungarian hottie Nikolett Barabas while Katy has been linked to French model Baptiste Giabiconi.

pages.headline: Salma opens up about acne hell
pages.teaser: HOLLYWOOD beauty suffered "severe, severe depression" from acne and was overweight when a struggling actress
pages.articlebody:
HOLLYWOOD beauty Salma Hayek has opened up about suffering "severe, severe depression" from acne and being overweight when a struggling actress.

The Latino star, one of the most beautiful stars in the movie business, insists it was a far different story when she was 25 and trying to break into movies.

"You want to talk about bad skin? I had acne," she told Lucky magazine in the U.S.

"And this acne was so bad it sent me into severe, severe depression.

"Like I couldn't leave the house.

"The next stage with that sort of depression is food - too little or too much. Guess what I did?

"I was fat and broken out. I couldn't leave the house and I couldn't pay the rent!"

She credits director Alfonso Cuaron for teaching her "to meditate, to relax" and also says Accutane "cured" the acne.

As for more drastic beauty treatments, she insists: "Botox - trust me, I've been tempted, but I resist!"

pages.subdeck: Simon Cowell ... will 'turn the show on its head'
pages.headline: BGT in crisis
pages.teaser: SHOW guru Cowell rips BGT apart following The Voice's ratings victory last week
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S Got Talent was in crisis last night as workaholic Simon Cowell ripped tonight's episode apart, ordering last-minute edits and rewrites as he seethed over The Voice's ratings victory last week.

The telly boss  who produces the show as well as sitting on the judging panel  ordered so many changes that yesterday no one on his staff was sure which acts would and wouldn't be included.

His team's frantic cutting even extended to ITV1 spin-off show Britain's Got More Talent, with host Stephen Mulhern ordered to catch the first train from Manchester and return to the north London studio to rework his links.

Last week the two shows overlapped by 20 minutes and, during that key time, The Voice beat Britain's Got Talent by a colossal three million.

While BGT started at 8pm with 5.9million viewers, The Voice  including coach Will.i.am  was still being watched by 9.3million after an hour on air. Stephen Mulhern told TV Biz yesterday afternoon: "Simon changes it up until the last minute, I've literally only just done the voice-over for the show that is going out tomorrow.

"He'll take stories out and he'll twist bits about and he'll say I don't want that there, and I want it there.

"He'll watch both shows throughout the week and chop them about, so I've had to come back in to re-do the voice-over.

"People don't realise how all over it he is.

"He is a judge but he also covers every bit of that show, there is not one bit that goes out that he hasn't signed off. I find if phenomenal, if not incredible."

Stephen admits he and the rest of the team weren't thrilled at being ordered in at the last minute. He said: "I had to come in twice! I was in Manchester last night so I had to travel back on the 7am train to be in for 9am, so they could deliver it to ITV for 1pm."

He revealed how Simon's attitude has completely changed.

He said: "We've had more conversations this year than we have in the past five years.

"The main thing he wanted to stress was that he was, and these were his words, 'Going to turn the show on its head'. "

Last week Simon admitted that as soon as he heard about The Voice's launch he flew his whole team out to America for an emergency meeting about how to revamp the show.

The changes, including hidden cameras, have gone down a storm.

Stephen added: "There is more reality in it and the hidden cameras are genius.

"It works really well. There is a lot more editing and work to do but on the flip side you have moments you could never write or create.

"Like last week, with Bradley and Barbara.

"She said, 'Bradley why don't you go to the toilet?' and he said, 'Barbara I don't need to go to the toilet'.

"And then Barbara said, 'You know what, Bradley? Whenever I go on holiday the first thing I think about when I go on a flight is, 'Prepare to die.' '

"I think those moments are genius."

pages.headline: The Mend booted off the X Factor to sing on BGT
pages.teaser: SIMON Cowell throws a BGT lifeline to a band he booted off The X Factor
pages.articlebody:
SIMON COWELL has thrown a lifeline to a band he booted off The X Factor  by giving them a slot on Britain's Got Talent.

The Mend were sent packing from last year's X Factor after it emerged they had broken the rules by having a manager.

But on the ITV1 show tonight the Manchester boyband wow the judges with a harmonised version of the Otis Redding classic (Sittin' On) The Dock Of The Bay  complete with a RAP.

Bosses were happy to have the boys  Kris Evans, Dean Kelly, Craig Worsley and Jay Kontzle  audition as BGT has no rules banning acts from having management. A source said: "The Mend were made up to get a decent look-in on BGT.

"They were worried about the whole X Factor thing, but Simon was relaxed about it.

"He's changed the rules on the X Factor now to allow bands with a manager to come on board, but The Mend didn't fancy waiting until then. They hope they can take BGT by storm and become the next One Direction."

Their boss, former Take That supremo Nigel Martin-Smith, hit the roof when they were kicked off X Factor. He felt Simon feared it would look like a fix as Take That's Gary Barlow was on the panel and liked the audition.

But last night Nigel had nothing but praise for Simon: "I was angry at the time, but to be fair to Simon he's let them back on one of his shows as soon as he could."

The Mend are not the only act enjoying a reality recycle as BGT follows rival show The Voice's lead.

We revealed yesterday that five familiar faces will be on the BBC1 talent show tonight. Now, Ryan O'Shaughnessy, who appeared on the Irish version of The Voice, will be the final act on BGT.

And X Factor flops Bejon will also appear on ITV2's Britain's Got More Talent with Stephen Mulhern.
