pages.subdeck: Warning ... health reports link alcohol to breast cancer risk
pages.headline: Why just ONE glass of wine might kill you
pages.teaser: STUDY shows drinking three or more a day can increase cancer risk by 40 PER CENT
pages.articlebody:
JUST one alcoholic drink a day can increase your risk of breast cancer, according to a new study.

Experts found even low and moderate drinkers had a five per cent greater risk of getting the disease.

Sinking three or more glasses a day can increase your risk of breast cancer by more than 40 PER CENT.

They say no woman should have more than ONE alcoholic drink a day  and those at a higher risk because of their family history should avoid booze completely.

Catherine Priestley, clinical nurse specialist at Breast Cancer Care, said: "This research says even light alcohol consumption could increase your risk.

"We think it can increase the levels of oestrogen in the body and this might increase the likelihood of breast cancer.

"The risk for every person is different. There may be teetotal women who develop breast cancer and there will always be women who drink a lot who don't get it.

"It's not as concrete as lung cancer and smoking but we would advise that people look at the information available and make an informed choice."

Here, we ask if you are drinking your way to breast cancer. Take the Sun Health quiz below to find out.



Take our test to discover your risk



1. HOW MANY DAYS OF THE WEEK DO YOU HAVE AN ALCOHOLIC DRINK?

1-2 (score 1 point)

3-4 (score 2 points)

5-6 (score 3 points)

Every day (score 4 points)

2. WHAT IS YOUR USUAL TIPPLE?

Spirit and mixer (score 1 point)

An alcopop (2 points)

Pint of lager (3 points)

175ml glass of wine (3 points)

250ml glass of wine (4 points)

3. HOW MANY DRINKS DO YOU TYPICALLY DRINK EACH DAY?

I don't drink alcohol (0 points)

1 (1 point)

2-3 (2 points)

4 or more (4 points)

4. HOW OFTEN DO YOU HAVE SIX OR MORE UNITS OF ALCOHOL ON ONE OCCASION?

Never (0 points)

Once a month (2 points)

2-4 times a month (3 points)

2-3 times a week (5 points)

5. HOW OLD WERE YOU WHEN YOU STARTED DRINKING?

15 or under (4 points)

16-18 (3 points)

18-21 (2 points)

21 or over (2 points)

6. HOW OFTEN DO YOU SUFFER FROM A HANGOVER?

More than once a week (4 points)

Once a week (3 points)

Twice a month (2 points)

Once a month (1 point)

7. DO YOU HAVE A FAMILY HISTORY OF BREAST CANCER?

Yes (1 point)

No (0 point)

8. DO YOU DRINK SOFT DRINKS IN BETWEEN ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES?

Yes (0 points)

No (2 points)

9. HOW OFTEN DO YOU EXERCISE?

Never (3 points)

1-2 times a week (2 points)

3-4 times a week (1 points)

5 times or more (0 points)

10. DO YOU DRINK BEFORE YOU GO OUT TO THE PUB?

Yes (2 points)

Sometimes (1 point)

No (0 points)



Scores and what they mean



OVER 30: DANGEROUS DRINKING. A greater chance of breast cancer, plus higher risk of liver disease, high blood pressure and stroke. Curb your drinking by changing your habits. You may also need help from your GP. Alcohol programmes are available in many areas.

21-30: HEAVY DRINKING. You could run a 40-50 per cent higher risk of breast cancer. There's also osteoporosis and high blood pressure to consider.

Try to avoid drinks that have become just a bad habit. Counselling may help you come to grips with problems that you can't see your way round at the moment. Again, your GP can help point you in the right direction. And see drinkaware.co.uk.

11-20: MODERATE DRINKING. You rarely overdo it and probably consider yourself a safe drinker. But the new research suggests that small amounts of alcohol, well below the current limits, can slightly increase the risk of breast cancer. They may also make fertility problems more common. Alternate soft drinks with alcoholic ones on an evening out.

Cutting down on alcohol can help you achieve your ideal weight because it is loaded with calories. Obesity increases the risk of breast cancer.

Keep active too. Lack of exercise can increase the risk of many common cancers, as well as heart disease.

0-10: ADMIRABLY RESTRAINED. But it's worth examining your lifestyle as a whole. A low-fat diet, regular exercise and giving up smoking will all give your health a boost.

pages.subdeck: Backing ... Hollyoaks actress Holly Weston
pages.headline: Meningitis kills teens as well as babies
pages.teaser: WITH a Hollyoaks character fighting for her life in the soap, actress who plays her reveals her support for new campaign
pages.byline: By HOLLY WESTON, Who gets struck down with the disease on Hollyoaks
pages.articlebody:
HOLLYOAKS student Ash Kane is fighting for her life in the Channel 4 soap  after being struck down with meningitis.

Ash initially put her symptoms down to a hangover. But in Tuesday's episode she collapsed and was rushed to hospital.

Holly Weston, 26  the actress who plays her  is backing Meningitis UK's Trust Your Instincts campaign.

Here, she tells us why.

I PLAY Hollyoaks party animal Ash, who was rushed to hospital with meningitis.

After a night out on the tiles, Ash woke up with a hangover after falling out with all her friends the night before.

When she complained of feeling unwell the next morning everyone just put it down to her usual melodramatics or the large amount of booze they thought she had drunk.

But Ash knew there was something wrong  she didn't drink enough to be that hungover and felt terrible.

During an argument with her sister, she collapses on the floor of the living room.

Not knowing what the problem is, her room mates call an ambulance and she is taken to hospital where she is diagnosed with meningitis and put into an induced coma.

It's touch and go whether she is going to be all right or whether she may be left with brain damage if she wakes up.

I knew very little about meningitis before tackling this storyline and during my research I was astonished to learn what an awful disease it is.

I had no idea that it could be so serious, that this disease can kill in just a few hours and leave people with permanent disabilities including loss of limbs and brain damage.

I also thought it was just something babies contracted.

I had no idea that it was so common in teenagers, who are the second most at-risk group after the under-fives.

Ash had some of the classic symptoms: Headache, a stiff neck and dislike of bright lights and feeling sick.

She put it down to flu but it soon became much more serious.

People always think of the rash  but this often doesn't appear until people are in a critical condition and there are many other symptoms to watch out for.

I am backing Meningitis UK's Trust Your Instincts campaign, which is encouraging people to seek urgent medical attention if they suspect meningitis.

The campaign encourages people to voice their concerns if they still fear something is wrong after seeking medical advice.

I hope that people read this and take notice that spotting the symptoms of meningitis early could save their life.

To request a free Meningitis UK symptoms fridge magnet to help you spot the signs of the disease, call 0117 947 6320 or visit the website meningitisuk.org.

pages.subdeck: Quirky ... Jessie J
pages.headline: What your clothes say about YOU
pages.teaser: BEHAVIOUR expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their fashion tells us about their personality
pages.articlebody:
MOST of us flash more flesh as the weather warms up but we may not realise what our outfits reveal about our personality.

A new book by US psychologist Dr Jennifer Baumgartner, You Are What You Wear: What Your Clothes Reveal About You, claims to unwrap the secrets behind our choice of outfits.

Here behaviour expert Dr Pam Spurr analyses six celebrities and reveals what their style says about them.

Jessie J



Style: The singer's outlandish styles show she likes to do things her own way.

Style secret: Eccentric dressers may seem extrovert but are often shy deep down. Their clothes may act as armour, diverting attention from them.

Cameron Diaz

Style: The film star's relaxed look indicates a more carefree and grounded personality.

Style secret: When someone feels they are seen chiefly as a sex object, they may downplay their feminine side to show there is more to their character.

Kate, Duchess of Cambridge

Style: As a younger Royal, Kate could push the boat out more with her outfits but plays it safe.

Style secret: Kate probably likes to maintain routine and please others. But some conservative dressers may long to break free.

Christina Hendricks

Style: The vampish Mad Men actress can seem aloof and untouchable.

Style secret: Someone who dresses like this may not feel sexy inside. She might be over-compensating to cover insecurity.

Beyonce

Style: The singer's trademark jewellery reveals a powerful personality who is happy to show she is on top.

Style secret: Lots of flash or expensive gear can mask a deeper insecurity that makes the wearer feel a need to prove themself.

Holly Willoughby

Style: Holly's style is feminine and traditional, but with a twist of sexiness.

Style secret: The girl next door may secretly wish to be more assertive and outgoing. Often more complicated than she appears.

pages.subdeck: Busker to beauty queen ... Miss England contestant Lena Walker
pages.headline: From busker to beauty queen
pages.teaser: ENCOURAGEMENT from passers-by led to teenager entering beauty pageant
pages.articlebody:
A STUNNING busker has turned Miss England hopeful after her fans encouraged her to enter the beauty pageant.

Lena Walker took to the streets of her home city of Leicester with her guitar to raise money for charity.

But the 17-year-old was surprised when scores of people approached her to praise her music  and her good looks.

The pretty student said: "I decided to give busking a go  but never expected the reaction I got.

"Loads of people were coming up to me and commenting on my music, but also my looks."

After entering the Miss England contest, she battled through several rounds to make the national finals.

She added: "I've always been a down-to-earth girl, so had never really considered putting myself in to be judged on my looks.

"But after my family and friends said I should do it, and with the confidence of all the comments from the public, I thought why not."

And after beating off competition from 22 other girls, she will now compete in the Miss England final in Leicester on June 26.

Lena said: "I don't think it has really hit me that I've made it into the last 60 girls left from the whole UK.

"I'm sure it will sink in once I'm on that stage."

And she says she's looking forward to competing in front of her home crowd.

She said: "Hopefully my down-to-earth nature will shine through and win me some support.

"I'll have plenty of family and friends there, what with it being held in my home town.

"It could be a struggle fitting them all in!"

If things don't work out, Lena may still have a career in music  as she raised a whopping £35 an hour while busking

But the big-hearted student donated the cash she raised to charities.

She added: "The public have been very generous whenever I have put myself on a limb and taken to the streets to play my music.

"I play a lot of my own stuff that I write, but also play a few crowd-pleasers like David Guetta, Jessie J and Foster The People.

"On a good day I've made £35 an hour and would stay for a couple of hours at least.

"It isn't all glamour though. I'd often get back from a session busking and your fingers would be numb thanks to the cold."

pages.subdeck: 'My photo journey reminds me how hard I worked' ... Nicola Williams
pages.headline: 11st weightloss picture diary
pages.teaser: TEACHER shares snaps she took every month until she reached her goal...a size 12
pages.articlebody:
WHEN primary school teacher Nicola Williams decided to lose weight, she looked to herself for inspiration.

She decided to take a self-portrait every month to clearly see her progress and motivate her to continue.

Her inspiring photo casebook charts her epic FOUR-YEAR weight loss  from 24 stone and a size 32 to the 13 stone size 12 she is today.

Her incredible photo diary helped her jack in the junk food and bin the bad habits in pursuit of a healthier, happier life.

Now, looking back through the pictures proves incredibly emotional for Nicola, 39.

She says: "When I show people they stare open-mouthed as I flick through the album and shrink before their eyes.

I can't believe how big I was and how much I've transformed. It's incredible and I love the new improved me.

"My photo journey reminds me of how hard I worked to get where I am today and I hope it inspires other women to begin their own journey."

At the age of 24, Nicola was 16 stone and by the time she was 34 she weighed 24st.

She recalls: "I worried if I was going to fit through a small gap or get stuck on a small chair. So I'd try to avoid putting myself in potentially embarrassing situations.

"For breakfast, I'd have four slices of toast. For lunch I'd make a sandwich with four slices of white bread with double the filling.

"Dinners were always whatever was quick. Pasta bakes, pizzas and takeaways were my regular meals of choice.

"My biggest weakness though, were crisps. I'd never go a day without eating at least three bags.

"Working as a primary school teacher, the staff room is always full of cakes and chocolates to snack on during break times."

Nicola, of Llanelli, Wales, was eating around 4,900 calories a day, 2,900 above the recommended intake. And it affected her confidence.

She says: "Trying to run around with the kids during PE lessons and teaching them about healthy lifestyles was always difficult as I felt like a hypocrite."

She also struggled to find clothes to flatter her huge frame. She continues: "I had to settle for T-shirts that managed to cover my enormous body and trousers that didn't dig in to my sides.

"The only things that looked good were shoes. I loved being able to walk into High Street shops and pick out a pair of pretty high heels, slip them on my feet and feel sexy.

"So I went crazy for them. Platforms, stilettos, boots, wedges  you name them, I had a pair. In every colour and for every occasion I had shoes that made me feel great.

"Worth more than £3,500, I had just over 100 pairs in my collection before my life changed."

Then, in December 2007, Nicola joined a weekly slimming class  purely to keep a friend company.

She says: "I swapped white bread for brown, reduced my portion sizes and snacked on fruit and veg. I found it surprisingly refreshing to come out of my normal convenience eating routine and try something new."

Within a month, Nicola had shed 10lb. Yet she struggled to see a difference in her appearance.

"So my friend suggested taking a picture to show me how well I'd done. It was the motivation I needed to carry on," she says.

"Comparing myself month by month stunned me. My face was thinner and I could notice the difference in my waistline and arms.

"I began looking forward to each month when the time came to take a picture and compare myself to the previous one."

Nicola also joined women-only gym Curves and began working out twice a week.

She says: "After the first year I'd lost five stone  down from 24st to 19st.

"My meals changed completely to consist of a piece of toast for breakfast, a sandwich with two pieces of brown bread for lunch, fruit for a snack and meat with vegetables for dinner.

"Looking at myself filled me with pride and the compliments I was receiving from friends and family were incredible.

"I was determined this wasn't going to just be a fad diet phase  this was a new lifestyle for me."

In the next three years she lost a further six stone, dropping to 13st 2lb.

Nicola says: "Every woman wants to look their best in a photo.

"If I was ever tempted to have a take-away binge at the end of the month, I'd think about having my picture taken and it would put me off."

And for shoe-mad Nicola there was only one way to mark her sensational new figure.

"In January this year I splashed out on a beautiful pair of £380 cream Jimmy Choo shoes to celebrate."

pages.subdeck: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman
pages.headline: 'Octomom' poses for topless snaps
pages.teaser: MUM-OF-FOURTEEN poses for topless snaps three years after having her octuplets
pages.articlebody:
MUM-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman shows off her incredible post-babies body in these revealing snaps.

Nadya, dubbed "Octomom" after giving birth to octuplets in 2009, happily posed topless for a magazine shoot.

And while she boasts of attracting plenty of admirers with her flat stomach and 34DD boobs, she claims she has been celibate for 13 years  as her children were all conceived through a sperm donor.

She explained: "I get way too much male attention, but I won't date until the octuplets are 18  I live for them now.

"I know a lot of women like male attention, but I'll go out with no make-up on and wear tracksuits, a wig and even a fake pregnancy stomach to put them off."

She added: "I wouldn't rule out a relationship in the future. But now, when men look at me, I look away and they know not to approach me.

"I know I'm beautiful  I don't need a man to tell me that."

Nadya, who lives in California, US, already had six kids  Elijah, now 10, Amerah, nine, Joshua, eight, Aiden, six, and twins Caleb and Calyssa, five, when she claims she decided to have more embryos implanted from the same sperm donor.

And her brood was soon joined by six boys and two girls  Noah, Jonah, Jeremiah, Isiah, Josiah, McCai, Maliah and Nariah, who turned three in January this year.

But amazingly, the 36-year-old says it was no effort at all to get her figure back following her last pregnancy.

She explained: "I just pinged back into shape like a rubber band after the kids  I don't know how I did it.

"I eat like a horse, don't count calories and have never owned a set of scales.

"I gained an entire human when I was pregnant with the octuplets  going from 10st to over 19st  but, two months later, I was a size eight again. Now, I never weigh myself."

  • The full feature appears in this month's Closer magazine, on sale now.

image.caption: Incredible figure ... mum-of-fourteen Nadya Suleman

pages.subdeck: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have
pages.headline: Go with the glow
pages.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk
pages.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).

pages.subdeck: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents
pages.headline: Renee's European parents
pages.teaser: ACTRESS Renee Zellweger reveals how her Norwegian mother influenced her career
pages.articlebody:
RENEE ZELLWEGER became a star thanks to her role opposite Tom Cruise in 1996 hit movie Jerry Maguire.

She is now established as one of the best-known and most highly paid actresses in Hollywood.

She won an Oscar for her role in the drama Cold Mountain and is famous for two films playing Bridget Jones.

Renee, 42, who had a short-lived marriage to singer Kenny Chesney in 2005, lives alone.

Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE about the influence her Norwegian-born mum Kjellfrid has had on her.

I DIDN'T grow up in a house where Mum focused on appearances. I don't remember her ever saying, "Wouldn't you be pretty if you did this or that?"

She never focused on anything beyond wanting me to be presentable  just well-groomed.

She wanted me to take care of myself and be healthy.

She did ask one or two questions when I became a cheerleader at high school because I would be teasing my hair and wearing lipstick and eyeliner.

I have an affiliation with a lot of countries. My mum was from Norway, my dad from Switzerland and my grandmother was Finnish, I have an Italian uncle, my first love was from South Africa and I was born in Texas.

I am definitely a Texan girl. It is a culture you really love in a Latin sort of way. You taste it and hear it and the climate is hot  Texas hot.

I felt lucky that my parents were European  different  and opened the doors to let me see America is not the centre of the universe.

It meant that, with Bridget Jones, I could go to London and enjoy all things English that make the country so wonderful.

During the making of the first film, I was even whistling songs by the Spice Girls.

But my mum was a realist about bringing up a teenage girl in America and kept a sense of humour.

She taught me that there are consequences for the things you say and do. She wanted me to grow up to be a good person. She and Dad liked simple and quiet. We had a very quiet house.

My mum didn't talk about her childhood growing up in Norway during the Second World War. Her sisters talked but all had difficulty in putting into words what they had seen.

They told about women giving birth in tunnels because there was no safe haven in any other structure.

And about being lost from family members and not being sure if they were alive.

So it was different for me, from my friends, growing up in a house where your mother was grateful just to have peace.

There was one thing which was never acceptable, though.

When I said: "I don't know how to do that", she would say: "Learn."

She encouraged me to get a college education (Renee has an English degree) as something to fall back on if acting didn't work out.

I moved to Los Angeles on December 6, 1993, to be exact.

My attitude was that I was going to see where it took me.

I had been working in Texas from the age of 21, and been in a couple of films. But I had pretty well exhausted my learning opportunities.

So I took a grungy little one-bed apartment and was scared to death of the future. It was a leap of faith, I guess.

I had some friends in LA who I had met on films but inside and emotionally, I felt alone.

To make a living, I worked in a bar called The Three Cubs on a street called Vine, behind the Mobil gas station.

It was an incredible place for a girl like me, who had lived in relatively safe places all her life.

There were crack deals being done on the street corners  so I would come back from the bar late at night then not be able to get out of my car to my apartment until the deals were completed.

I worked at the bar for two years. That was why Mum's guidance was so important and I stayed happy.

When you can take care of yourself and see your friends, that is all that matters.

The main difference that the film Jerry Maguire made in my life was I could pay my rent and didn't have to waitress any more. It gave me freedom.

I knew from the start that if I failed in acting, I always had my degree and could try a million things. I was not a "look at me" kind of girl.

I had gravitated toward acting because I had a vivid imagination and daydreamed a lot.

But I did not daydream about being on a film set, winning an Oscar or having people know my name.

I am grateful for the fact my mum never worried that I would compromise myself.

She was always telling me, 'You don't sit down enough'  but she learned to trust my instincts.

article.caption: Jerry Maguire actor's grown up to be a big star

Dec, who revealed he had been on a diet and working out, said: "I like a bit of fun and it didn't make me laugh."

Of the TV clash, he said: "The audience should be able to watch both."

The presenters revealed producers had once wanted them to change roles on BGT and become judges.

They also hinted at one of the wackiest acts coming up on BGT. Ant said: "There is one dog so good I had to check it wasn't a dwarf in a dog suit."

pages.subdeck: Got it licked ... star Jeff Salmon knew he'd make a killing if Royal Mail's price hike was approved
pages.headline: Four Rooms star Jeff makes £250,000 investment in stamps
pages.teaser: TV art dealer Jeff Salmon forks out on stamps as the Royal Mail plans to hike their prices
pages.articlebody:
TELLY art dealer Jeff Salmon splashed out £250,000 on STAMPS after the Royal Mail revealed plans to hike their prices.

And he reckons he'll now make tens of thousands of pounds in profit by selling them on.

The star of primetime Channel 4 auction show Four Rooms spotted a chance to cash in earlier this year when his WIFE told him about the national postal service's proposed price rises.

And he was rubbing his hands this week after the hike was given the go-ahead.

The rise will add 39 per cent and 30 per cent respectively to the cost of second and first-class delivery, from April 30.

Jeff now plans to sell the lot to companies by undercutting the price rise to net him "the easiest money of his career".

Jeff said: "When my wife Lucia pointed out the price of stamps was going to go up earlier this year, I placed an order for £250,000-worth of first and second class stamps.

"I didn't look at the price rise as a bad thing, but as an opportunity.

"It was everywhere in the newspapers and was an obvious thing to do  putting your money on a one-horse race.

"I mean, how nice of Royal Mail to give the public a window to buy them at the cheaper price before actually raising them.

"It was a no-brainer. Now they have decided stamps will go up by an average of about 35 per cent I will sell them off to a large commercial company for 25 per cent more than I paid for them.

"Whoever buys them will be getting a great deal and will bite my hands off  and I will make the easiest money of my career."

First and second class stamps will go up 14p to 60p and 50p respectively.

The price increases  the biggest for 37 years  were announced after regulator Ofcom warned an explosion in text messages, emails and social network websites was threatening the postal network's future.

pages.articlebody:
KEITH LEMON sure looks McFly! The Celebrity Juice host cruises around in the Back To The Future DeLorean to plug his new helping hand show Lemonaid.

The ITV1 show, which starts on April 7, sees Lemon  comic Leigh Francis  bomb round the country doing bizarre favours for folk.

They include giving a bald man a full head of hair, turning a schoolboy into a mini-Keith Lemon and getting a buff toyboy to carry a granny's shopping.

  • SIR Trevor McDonald got a shock when he met a marshmallow-loving alligator called Cherie.

    The former newsreader was filming his new ITV1 show, The Mighty Mississippi With Trevor McDonald, when his guide Tucker Freedom lured the reptile closer to their boat.

    He said: "I didn't know alligators liked marshmallows! It felt unreal to be in a Louisiana swamp with an alligator which responded to its name and which had a passion for sweets."

  • A NEW comedy show will be hoping to make a big impression by mocking the world's obsession with celebs and gossip.

    Channel 4's Very Important People stars Morgana Robinson and Terry Mynott and celebs impersonated include Perez Hilton, Fearne Cotton, Bear Grylls, Simon Cowell and Adele.

    Fiona McDermott, commissioning editor of Channel 4, said: "VIP's talented new faces have captured the quirks of dozens of modern celebrities."

pages.subdeck: Court bid ... ex-Big Brother star Brian Belo
pages.headline: Big Brother's Brian Belo in Towie tapes demand
pages.teaser: THE former BB star wants ITV to hand over EVERY copy of The Only Way Is Essex
pages.articlebody:
BIG BROTHER's Brian Belo has demanded ITV hand over ALL copies of The Only Way Is Essex.

We told this week how the BB winner is suing the channel and producer Lime Pictures for allegedly ripping off the idea for his show Totally Essex  which the firms deny.

In his High Court writ, made public last night, besides calling for an injunction to stop Towie airing he asks "for delivery up and forfeiture" of all "infringing articles" including "all copies of The Only Way Is Essex".

The 13-page writ also includes correspondence between Lime Pictures and Brian in which he is asked for help sourcing "contact details of individuals within the Format".

Brian's Totally Essex show, which he pitched to ITV, featured Mark Wright, Kirk Norcross, Sam Faiers and Amy Childs  who all later appeared in Towie.

The writ also notes when quizzed about the origins of the Towie name at the Edinburgh TV festival last year a senior ITV executive "confirmed that the original title proposed for Towie was Totally Essex".

ITV and Lime Pictures have denied ripping Brian off and said the claim will be "vigorously defended".

  • TIME Lord Matt Smith will once again battle against the Daleks in the new series of Doctor Who.

    The cyborgs last featured in 2010. The drama's website said: "The Daleks are being wheeled before the cameras once again. But which design? The answer is ALL OF THEM!"

pages.subdeck: Big fan ... Sun's Ally Ross on the show
pages.headline: Fans furious after Total Wipeout gets BBC axe
pages.teaser: VIEWERS vent their anger on social networking sites after family favourite gets boot
pages.articlebody:
TOTAL Wipeout fans were furious last night after the BBC axed the hugely popular show.

The decision came as a shock and many viewers logged on to social networking sites to vent their fury.

The BBC1 family favourite, which is hosted by Top Gear's Richard Hammond and Amanda Byram sees contestants take part in a giant wacky obstacle course above a huge pool of water.

One of the most popular parts of the course is when the plucky contestants have to bounce off giant red balls, with many ending up in the water. Even Sun columnist Ally Ross had a go at tackling the tricky course last year.

But the Beeb said the show, together with its spin-off series Winter Wipeout and the celebrity versions, will end after the next series later this year. Last night angry viewers took to Twitter to slam the BBC. Fans also called on rival channels such as Sky1 to snap up the series.

Sun man Ally, a big Total Wipeout fan, said: "Even by the standards of the BBC this is a dumb decision. It is the only funny show the Beeb broadcast, apart from The Apprentice. Television just got a lot duller. I am spitting feathers."

A BBC spokesman told TV Biz: "After four successful series of Total Wipeout, and one series of Winter Wipeout, the BBC has taken the decision that the next series will be the last."

The Saturday night show  which is filmed in Argentina  often attracts more than 4.5million viewers.

pages.subdeck: Pop dinosaur ... Denise Pearson of Eighties band Five Star
pages.headline: Voice sounds familiar  BBC show packed with recycled faces
pages.teaser: FIVE of the 11 acts on the show's blind auditions are already known to audiences
pages.articlebody:
THE show's new  the acts most certainly are not.

Viewers of The Voice will rightly be thinking they've heard it all before when they watch tomorrow.

FIVE of the 11 contestants in the blind auditions are already familiar to us.

One is a recycled singer from the Eighties, THREE others are X Factor failures and one is a West End star.

The news is sure to disappoint the hosts of nobodies hoping that the series could launch them into stardom.

The opening episode last week saw ex-5ive boyband member Sean Conlon snubbed. Not one of the mentors  Tom Jones, Jessie J, Will.i.am or The Script's Danny O'Donoghue  thought he was good enough to go through.

This week's pop dinosaur is Denise Pearson of Eighties band Five Star.

She will be competing for the judges' attention with Kerry Ellis, who filled in on the West End stage for Martine McCutcheon in My Fair Lady and performed in Wicked.

Then there are those rejected X Factor wannabes.

Vince Kidd made the final 12 four years ago as a member of boyband Futureproof under his real name Matthew Protheroe.

His single Sick Love  which had a controversial video featuring "nuns" in S&M gear  was co-written with 2007 X Factor winner Leon Jackson.

Glamorous gran Barbara Bryceland made it to bootcamp the same year and is hoping she will hit the big time on The Voice with her rendition of Wild Horses.

The last member of the unholy trinity is two-time X Factor failure Heshima Thompson, booted out by the panel in both 2009 and last year.

His other claims to fame are as a backing singer for the late Amy Winehouse and a career on TV.

The singer and actor has appeared in Spooks, EastEnders: E20, The Bill and Prime Suspect alongside Dame Helen Mirren. He will be acting out his dream tomorrow by performing Taoi Cruz's hit Dynamite.

Among those up against the famous flops tomorrow are builder David Faulkner, a finalist in the non-televised regional talent show Welsh Factor and former supermarket shelf-stacker David Julien, from unsigned Manchester-based indie band In The Grey.

Cheeky Aleks Josh from Stevenage, Herts; barefoot Cheltenham balladeer Vince Freeman; teenage barmaid Frances Wood; and childhood sweethearts Matt & Sueleen, from Canterbury, Kent, will also appear.

So will it be Old Hat or New Blood that triumphs on the night? See BBC1 at 7pm tomorrow to find out.

pages.subdeck: Over the Moon ... Tony Discipline and Jacqueline Jossa cosy up together
pages.headline: Enders lovebirds at premiere
pages.teaser: REAL life soap couple tread the red carpet together at Wrath Of The Titans premiere
pages.articlebody:
EASTENDERS lovebirds Jacqueline Jossa and Tony Discipline made their red carpet debut as a couple at the premiere for Wrath Of The Titans last night.

Jacqueline, 19, who plays Lauren Branning on the BBC1 soap, wore a blue bandage dress for the event while Tony, 22, alias Tyler Moon, donned a smart grey suit for the bash.

The film boasts an all-star cast including Sam Worthington, Liam Neeson, Bill Nighy and Ralph Fiennes and is a sequel to Clash Of The Titans.

Jacqueline has previously revealed that she met Tony before he joined the cast but spurned his advances.

She said: "It was at my favourite nightclub. Tony came up and said he was auditioning for EastEnders. I didn't believe him, though when I walked back to my mates, I was like, 'Did you see his teeth?! He's well fit!'

"But I left it. I didn't think he was going to join EastEnders. He even added me on Facebook and I deleted him! Then a couple of months later, I came into work and there he was. I called my cousin and said, 'Do you remember Fit Boy? He is in the building'."

She added: "We didn't get together for ages, as we thought it'd be weird on set, but it got to the point where there was no other option.

"We kept it a secret at first, but everyone was like, 'Oh, we knew'. Tony is very romantic - he got me a teddy bear for our two-week anniversary. But we're not cheesy, we find the same things funny and that's important."

Earlier this year, Jacqueline was awarded the Most Popular Newcomer gong at the National Television Awards.

She said at the time: "It still all feels ridiculous.

"My mum's put the NTA award on the mantelpiece. But it's not sunk in yet."

The former Big Brother star is known for her voluptuous figure and is a lads' mag favourite and it's easy to see why.

Presenter Lisa Snowdon also posted a sexy photo of her cleavage online.

Xtra Factor host and singer Olly Murs tweeted his delight at hearing what day it was.

Even ex Strictly Robbie Savage tried to get in on the action, posted a photo with the message: "Heh #nationalclevegeday what you reckon.

"Happy cleavage day everyone lol lol !!"

And former Dancing On Ice star Laura Hamilton, who is is engaged to insurance broker Alex Goward, wrote: "Alex informs me it's national cleavage day today? Did he make that up? He he."

Imogen recently moaned that she'd wolfed down too many snacks while on holiday in Thailand earlier this month, and booked herself into a bootcamp.

Well she's got a point, she's busting out of her clothes.

pages.subdeck: Famous face ... Nick Hewer
pages.headline: Apprentice star Nick Hewer: I'll get Botox to keep my face still
pages.teaser: COUNTDOWN host famed for raising eyebrow at contestants says he may get injections
pages.articlebody:
APPRENTICE star Nick Hewer  famed for raising a despairing eyebrow at contestants  says he is planning to get BOTOX to halt his facial expressions.

The new Countdown host, 68, insists his famed frown could soon be a thing of the past as he is looking at following Apprentice boss Lord Sugar in having a cosmetic procedure.

The tycoon has had bags around his eyes removed and Nick, who is into the eighth series as Lord Sugar's right-hand man, admits the eyebrow raising has taken its toll.

He said: "I don't realise when I'm doing the frown.

"I've got a very mobile face and I think the cameramen pick up on it. I'm thinking I might have Botox to make it impossible to raise my eyebrows.

"It's not like I practise it in the mirror. No one makes me raise my eyebrows on cue. I am what I am. Nobody would have the nerve to ask me to do something to suit the cameras and there are no retakes."

Nick's deadly gaze has already claimed its first victim this year after he presided over the girls' team Sterling and their printing task in the first week.

Their failure saw risk analyst Bilyana Apostolova given the sack.

She was followed into the black taxi this week by this year's youngest contestant Maria O'Connor, who Hewer had branded a "very loud young lady".

Despite having a clear influence on who gets the boot, Nick insists not even he can tell Lord Sugar who gets fired. He said: "If anyone dared to tell Alan who to fire, he'd hit the roof.

"We never know who he is going to fire right up until the very moment he does it."

article.caption: The Apprentice unveiled
Countdown host slams soap violence
Nick Hewer is not lost for words on Countdown

pages.subdeck: BGT hopeful ... Sam Kelly
pages.headline: Britain's Got Talent Sam Kelly: Delia Smith is so tasty
pages.teaser: SINGER has been inundated with offers from frisky women but only has eyes for TV chef
pages.articlebody:
BRITAIN'S Got Talent hopeful Sam Kelly has been inundated with offers from frisky women since singing about his heartbreak on Saturday.

But he says he has his eye on one woman only  chef and top Norwich City fan Delia Smith.

Sam said: "I have had a couple of date offers on Twitter but I think they would probably have a rethink if they met me. I'm a bit of a geek, really. I'm a massive Canaries fan  if I can find someone like Delia I'd be delighted. Plus I would never go hungry!"

On Tuesday we told how Sam's experience with an unfaithful ex motivated him to sing Adele's Make You Feel My Love on BGT.

He said he tapped into painful memories for the heartfelt rendition.

He said: "My last girlfriend cheated on me. She is not a very nice person actually, so it is probably a good thing."

pages.subdeck: DOUBLE TOPS ... Sebastian Larsson seriously harmed City's title hopes
pages.headline: Man City 3 Sunderland 3
pages.teaser: ALEKSANDAR KOLAROV levelled late for City  but their title hopes were still dented
pages.articlebody:
ALEKSANDAR KOLAROV capped a dramatic comeback for Manchester City with a late equaliser against Sunderland.

But the Black Cats, through Seb Larsson's double, still seriously dented the title aspirations of Roberto Mancini's men at the Etihad Stadium.

The Swedish midfielder netted the opener on 31 minutes, only for Mario Balotelli to level two minutes before the break with a disputed penalty.

Martin O'Neill's side were in no mood to go into half time behind however, with a Nicklas Bendtner planting home a header.

Danish frontman Bendtner then turned provider 10 minutes into the second period, allowing Larsson to open up a two-goal lead.

A cracking goal from Balotelli on 85 minutes gave City hope of clawing something back, with Kolarov duly delivering for the home side moments later.

But the result still leaves City sitting two points behind rivals Manchester United  who now have the chance to extend that lead to five with victory at Blackburn on Monday night.

City had welcomed back influential captain Vincent Kompany after four games out, while Sunderland were forced to leave out on-loan left-back Wayne Bridge against his parent club.

The visitors were lively early on and had a good chance to go ahead after 15 minutes with Sessegnon twice involved in a sweeping move  only for Craig Gardnerto hit the side netting.

City responded with Dzeko testing Mignolet and Kompany, back in the side after a calf injury, scuffed a shot wide from the resulting corner.

Richards won a corner which Balotelli headed over and City began to show signs of frustration.

Gardner found McClean on the edge of the area with a smart reverse pass and the Irishman turned to fire narrowly wide.

Bendtner then had a shot blocked before the Black Cats grabbed a deserved lead just after the half-hour.

Larsson did the damage with a superb finish after Sessegnon found space on the left and picked out the Swede inside the D.

The Swede had defenders blocking his sight but had enough room to flick a low shot with the inside of his boot beyond Joe Hart's reach into the bottom corner.

City tried to respond quickly and Yaya Toure was angered when he was dragged back by Kilgallon as he raced towards the area.

Mignolet saved the resulting free-kick from Kolarov and follow-up efforts from Milner and Richards were blocked.

Balotelli wanted a penalty after going down in the area.

Referee Phil Dowd waved play on but did point to the spot moments later after Dzeko jumped into a challenge with Gardner.

Sunderland were furious at the decision but Balotelli kept his cool to level with a clever spot-kick.

An argument broke out between Dzeko and Phil Bardsley when play was stopped following a clash of heads between Richards and Jack Colback.

Balotelli proved an unlikely peacemaker and play eventually restarted.

City may have wished it had not as Sunderland reclaimed the lead in first-half injury time when Bendtner planted a firm header past Hart from a Sessegnon cross.

City boss Mancini made an attacking change at the start of the second half by sending on winger Adam Johnson for Richards and dropping Milner back to right-back.

Yaya Toure needed treatment and continued to look uncomfortable after being caught by Lee Cattermole in midfield.

The City talisman was then beaten to the ball inside his own half as Sessegnon launched the attack which led to Sunderland's third.

Bendtner raced into space down the right and played a low ball into the box for Larsson, who timed his run perfectly to slide in at the far post.

Mancini's response was to send on Tevez for Silva and the hosts spurned a chance moments later as Kolo Toure headed over from a corner.

City won a free-kick after Kolarov went down on the edge of the area and frustrations boiled over as the hosts could not decide who should take it.

Balotelli clearly wanted to be involved and reacted unhappily when Tevez lined up behind the ball.

Kompany had to push the Italian away and in the end it was Kolarov who took it, curling a shot wide.

Tevez had his first chance as City broke from deep but hit the side netting from the edge of the area.

Bendtner missed a fine chance to make it 4-1 when he fired over from the edge of the box and City finally stirred into life.

Balotelli reduced the arrears with a fine goal, all of his own making, five minutes from time as he came in from the left and ran across the edge of the box to beat Mignolet from distance.

The hosts threw everything into attack and were rewarded again as substitute David Pizarro rolled the ball wide for Kolarov to smash home.

Despite some frantic late scenes, however, City could not claim a winner.

Man City: Hart, Richards (Johnson 46), Toure, Kompany, Kolarov, Milner (Pizarro 81), De Jong, Toure Yaya, Silva (Tevez 58), Balotelli, Dzeko Subs Not Used: Pantilimon, Clichy, Barry, Zabaleta. Booked: De Jong.

pages.subdeck: SHARP SHOOTER ... QPR star Adel Taarabt wheels away in celebration after opening the scoring
pages.headline: QPR 2 Arsenal 1
pages.teaser: ADEL TAARABT and Samba Diakite did the damage as Gunners' win streak ended
pages.articlebody:
BATTLING QPR ended Arsenal's winning run  and boosted their survival hopes.

The R's earned a hard-fought 2-1 victory to climb level on 28 points with Blackburn.

Former Tottenham midfielder Adel Taarabt fired the hosts into the lead on 22 minutes with his first Premier League goal.

Arsenal levelled through Theo Walcott 15 minutes later, but Rangers snatched what could prove a priceless three points through Samba Diakite mid-way through the second half.

QPR captain Joey Barton had used his pre-match programme notes to call for the Rs fans to get behind him after being booed off the pitch while being substituted during the win over Liverpool 10 days ago.

But the controversial midfielder received a mixed reception when his name was read out ahead of kick off.

Walcott made early progress down the right channel, forcing a corner which was eventually hacked clear.

Arsenal continued to press without stretching the home side.

On seven minutes, Clint Hill bundled Walcott over to concede a free-kick just right of centre, 25 yards out.

Robin van Persie struck a low, curled effort goalwards, which Paddy Kenny gathered at the second attempt, with Walcott looking to pounce on the loose ball.

Rangers were soon on the offensive, with Alex Song needing to make a couple of important blocks as Bobby Zamora threatened.

The home side continued to push Arsenal back, and Zamora sent a free header over from 10 yards after a deep free-kick into the area.

But QPR broke the deadlock on 22 minutes.

Taarabt collected a pass from the halfway line, before turning Thomas Vermaelen on the edge of the penalty area and dispatching the ball into the bottom corner.

Moroccan Taarabt celebrated by donning a fez that he then threw into the crowd, but referee Mike Dean took a dim view of his actions and brandished a yellow card.

Arsenal needed to regroup, but had been in this situation more than once recently and recovered to secure victory.

But QPR remained full of energy, with Taarabt enjoying plenty of the ball.

Arsenal were level on 37 minutes with their first real chance.

Van Persie made space on the edge of the area and stabbed the ball to Walcott.

The England winger cracked a first-time effort off the base of the far post, and was quickest to the rebound, hooking in his seventh Premier League goal of the season.

Arsenal began to pass the ball around with confidence, Aaron Ramsey dragging a low shot from 20 yards across goal and wide.

The visitors pressed again at the start of the second half, as Bacary Sagna floated over a deep cross from the right which fellow full-back Kieran Gibbs nodded just wide.

QPR were now finding it difficult to retain much possession, and then gave the ball away when looking to build a break.

On 57 minutes, Kenny punched away an angled free-kick from Van Persie.

The Dutchman was denied again by the QPR keeper after spinning off his marker and racing into the penalty area.

QPR then went ahead for the second time on 66 minutes.

Vermaelen slipped again, allowing Jamie Mackie to skip into the penalty and pulled the ball back for Diakite to slam home.

Arsenal needed another response and on 69 minutes, Gervinho replaced Ramsey.

QPR soaked up plenty of pressure, but also looked dangerous on the break as Arsenal committed men forwards.

With 10 minutes left, Mikel Arteta was replaced by Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain and Marouane Chamakh came on for Gibbs.

Barton almost sealed it when his effort was tipped over by Wojciech Szczesny after another break by Mackie down the right.

The late Arsenal fightback never materialised as Rangers closed out four minutes of stoppage time to boost their hopes of staying up.

pages.subdeck: WONDER BRA ... two-goal Ivanovic give Blues a lift
pages.headline: Aston Villa 2 Chelsea 4
pages.teaser: BRANISLAV IVANOVIC and Fernando Torres kept Chelsea's top-four dream alive in this Villa thriller
pages.articlebody:
BRANISLAV IVANOVIC and Fernando Torres kept Chelsea's top-four dream alive in this Villa thriller.

The Blues were cruising after Daniel Sturridge and Ivanovic had netted either side of the break.

But Villa hauled themselves back into it when James Collins and Eric Lichaj scored in a lightning two-goal burst.

Yet there was still time for more drama and Ivanovic grabbed his second before Torres made the points safe late on.

It means Chelsea are now just two points off the Champions League places.

Villa skipper Stiliyan Petrov was watching from the stands  just a day after he was diagnosed with leukaemia.

And his team-mates carved out the first chance, with Ashley Cole clearing Andreas Weimann's cross.

Chelsea, though, soon hit their straps and Shay Given had to be alert to deny Torres. And the visitors were ahead after just nine minutes.

Sturridge crashed home from close range after a pinball scramble following Salomon Kalou's cross.

It was nearly 2-0 when John Obi Mikel's thunderbolt hit Collins  and deflected straight to Shay Given.

And the Blues then went even closer when Juan Mata hit the post and Torres saw his follow-up blocked.

Villa started to regroup but Barry Bannan's curling free-kick was dealt with by Michael Essien.

Frank Lampard then deflected a Warnock cross just wide before Nathan Baker volleyed over from the resulting corner.

Petr Cech's sensational 43rd-minute save stopped Villa levelling before the break.

Weimann played the ball to Agbonlahor, who spun sharply 10 yards out before firing in a powerful low drive.

But Cech somehow managed to deflect the shot over the bar.

Former Villa defender Gary Cahill replaced Luiz, who had suffered a knock, on the stroke of half-time.

Six minutes after the break, Chelsea doubled their lead.

Torres attacked a Mata corner and brushed the ball to Ivanovic, who turned in past Given.

Di Matteo's men looked in complete command and seemed to be cruising to three points.

But on 77 minutes, Collins gave Villa a glimmer of hope when he nodded home Lichaj's throw-in.

An amazing comeback was on the cards  and Lichaj sent Villa Park wild by converting Marc Albrighton's corner just three minutes later.

Incredibly, the drama did not end there.

Ivanovic smashed home on 83 minutes in a carbon copy on his first. And Torres got in on the act when he wrapped up the points in the final moments.

Aston Villa: Given, Lichaj, Collins, Baker, Warnock, Gardner, Herd (Albrighton 70), Agbonlahor, Ireland, Bannan, Weimann (Heskey 82). Subs Not Used: Guzan, Johnson, Williams, Carruthers, Grealish. Booked: Warnock.

pages.subdeck: CARROLL STINGER ... Andy is worried he will cop flak
pages.headline: Don't hate me
pages.teaser: LIVERPOOL'S Geordie striker returns to St James' Park hoping for a good reception
pages.articlebody:
ANDY CARROLL has begged Newcastle fans: Don't hate me.

Liverpool's Geordie striker returns to St James' Park tomorrow and said: "If I scored I would not celebrate. I thought I did well for the club when I was there.

"I loved it and have some great memories from playing there."

Tomorrow's clash will be Carroll's first visit to the Toon since his £35million Kop move in January 2011.

The 23-year-old added: "I hope I get a good reception from the fans  they'll get one from me.

"I've always had a good relationship with the Newcastle fans and it stems back to playing for them.

"I still love the club and have a lot of friends at Newcastle. I always want to see them doing well.

"I want to do well for Liverpool but when I come off the pitch, Newcastle is the first score I look for.

"That will always be the case. I want to see them win because I'm a fan."

article.caption: I don't regret a thing

pages.subdeck: WINNER ... QPR defender Samba Diakite scores to shoot down Arsenal
pages.headline: Harry high as a Kite
pages.teaser: HARRY REDKNAPP delighted as QPR stunned Spurs' Champions League rivals Arsenal
pages.articlebody:
HARRY REDKNAPP revealed he nearly jumped for joy when Samba Diakite scored QPR's winner against Arsenal.

Tottenham boss Redknapp was in attendance as the R's earned a 2-1 victory at Loftus Road to end the Gunners' seven-match winning streak.

The defeat leaves Arsenal third in the Premier League  three points ahead of fourth-placed Spurs, who play Swansea today.

Chelsea are also just two points off the Champions League places after beating Aston Villa 4-2.

And it means the race for a place in Europe's premier club competition looks set to go down to the wire.

Redknapp said: "I was very tempted to celebrate QPR's winning goal!

"That was a big result for them today and a setback for Arsenal. You'd have fancied them to win at Loftus Road but it wasn't to be.

"And obviously Chelsea won so it's going to be close between the three of us.

"You enjoy it when results go your way. Arsenal losing, Chelsea getting pulled back to 2-2 with 10 minutes to go, I'm thinking 'this could be a really great day.'

"And then Chelsea came back to beat Aston Villa  it's exciting."

Tottenham have picked up just TWO points from their last five league games but can go level with Arsenal if they win this afternoon.

But Redknapp warned his squad to expect a tough battle against Brendan Rodgers' side.

Speaking to Absolute Radio, he added: "We need to beat Swansea to make use of Arsenal's result.

"They are a good side and it will be a difficult game.

"We've been playing well enough but have had a couple of setbacks.

"We played well in the defeats against Manchester United and at Everton and I thought we played well when we drew against Chelsea last week.

"We've not been on a downer as far as the form goes but it just shows you how diffiult it is to win games when you look at Arsenal's result."

image.caption: WINNER ... QPR defender Samba Diakite scores to shoot down Arsenal
DELIGHTED ... Harry Redknapp saw QPR dent Arsenal's top four bid

pages.subdeck: NICE ONE, PET ... Martin Petrov pays tribute to Bulgarian team-mate Stiliyan Petrov after scoring
pages.headline: Wolves 2 Bolton 3
pages.teaser: SURVIVAL hopes looking slim for Terry Connor's men after Trotters come from behind to win
pages.articlebody:
WOLVES' survival hopes were dealt a hammer blow as Bolton came from behind to win at Molineux.

Terry Connor's side looked like they might secure their first win under the interim boss when Michael Kightly put the hosts in front after 53 minutes.

But Martin Petrov restored parity from the penalty spot 10 minutes later before Marcos Alonso put the visitors in front.

And it looked all over when Kevin Davies slotted past Wayne Hennessey to make it 3-1.

Matt Jarvis managed to pull one back with two minutes to play but Connor's men couldn't find an equaliser.

It was a priceless win for Bolton in the fight to stay in the Premier League but things are looking bleak for Wolves as they remain rooted to the bottom of the table and six points from safety.

Connor's men made a positive start, with Kightly looking a threat down the right flank and a couple of corners causing panic in the Bolton box.

Kightly then lofted a free-kick forward which Steven Fletcher did well to keep in and the ball came to Ebanks-Blake, who brought a save out of Adam Bogdan with a snap-shot.

The Trotters served a warning at the other end, Petrov seeing an effort blocked by Richard Stearman and miscuing an attempted volley moments later.

Bogdan then did brilliantly to claw away Fletcher's header, but the hosts were looking vulnerable at the back and after Trotters striker Ivan Klasnic was allowed to get a shot away, Wolves skipper Johnson and goalkeeper Hennessey squared up to each other.

Wolves looked to pick up where they left off as the second half got under way, but they survived a scare as David Wheater glanced Ryo Miyaichi's cross just the wrong side of the post.

The hosts' dominance finally paid off eight minutes after the restart, though, as Kightly received the ball from Ebanks-Blake, darted past Alonso and arrowed a shot beyond Bogdan into the corner of the net.

The home supporters breathed a sigh of relief, but within 10 minutes Bolton had equalised as ex-Wolves man Mark Davies went down after being challenged by Johnson in the box and Petrov buried the resulting spot-kick.

As part of his celebration, the Bulgarian revealed a T-shirt displaying a message of support for his compatriot Stiliyan, the Aston Villa captain who has been diagnosed with acute leukaemia.

The Trotters wide man then almost added another, unleashing a stinging drive that Hennessey managed to save, and struck a free-kick at the goalkeeper moments later.

With just under 15 minutes to go, Jarvis blew a chance to put his side back in front by heading wide when he should have done better, and it proved costly.

Three minutes later Ngog headed Petrov's cross against the bar and Alonso had little trouble converting from close range.

Bolton then swiftly extended their lead as one substitute Chris Eagles had the space to find another, Kevin Davies, who slotted past Hennessey.

Jarvis gave Wolves hope by pulling one back two minutes from time but it was too little too late.

pages.subdeck: FAN FAVOURITE ... Stilian Petrov thanks the Villa crowd for their support
pages.headline: Cancer-hit Petrov at Villa game
pages.teaser: BRAVE Bulgarian skipper cheers on team-mates despite leukaemia diagnosis
pages.articlebody:
BRAVE Stiliyan Petrov was at Aston Villa today to support his football team-mates  just 24 hours after news of his leukaemia diagnosis was made public.

The Bulgarian midfielder, who insisted the game with Chelsea went ahead, stood in an executive box to acknowledge the cheers of supporters.

News of skipper Petrov's illness has touched the footballing world, with clubs across the country offering their support.

And after he arrived at Villa Park, a statement was released thanking everyone for the tributes.

Petrov said: "I would like to thank all of the people who have left messages of support. The response has been overwhelming and I appreciate it very much.

"This is a difficult time for my family and myself and I ask people to respect my privacy.

"With the help and love of my family, my team-mates, all of my friends in football, Aston Villa and all of the fans, I am sure I will beat this illness and I am determined to do this."

Petrov, 32, revealed the remarkable recovery of Bolton midfielder Fabrice Muamba, who was pictured yesterday upright and smiling as he recuperates from his cardiac arrest at White Hart Lane two weeks ago, would be a source of inspiration.

He added: "I saw the picture released yesterday by Fabrice Muamba, my fellow player, and it has inspired me as has all of the support in the past 24 hours.

"For me, football will have to take a back seat for a while, but I'm here to support my team-mates today and I will continue to support them as I know they will support me. Thank you to everyone."

Both Villa and Chelsea players wore T-shirts in honour of the former Celtic ace during the warm-up.

The statement was read out just before this afternoon's match to applause and chants of 'There's only one Stiliyan Petrov' from all sections of the crowd.

Villa fans stood and applauded during the 19th minute of the match, in reference to the fact Petrov - known as Stan - wears the No19 shirt.

The Villa skipper had made a trip to London yesterday after his diagnosis was revealed but returned to the West Midlands last night to attend today's fixture, which Villa lost 2-4.

The blood cancer was diagnosed after Petrov had complained of suffering with a fever following last week's 3-0 defeat at Arsenal.

pages.subdeck: GREAT READ ... Sugar Ray Leonard's autobiography is available now in all good book shops
pages.headline: One on One with Sugar Ray Leonard
pages.teaser: WATCH SunSport's video interview with boxing legend Sugar Ray Leonard
pages.articlebody:
THE term 'legend' is often overused  but it sums up Sugar Ray Leonard perfectly.

After winning gold at the 1976 Olympics, Leonard turned professional and went on to lift world titles in FIVE weight classes.

When he hung up his gloves for good, the American walked away from boxing with 36 wins, one draw and just three losses from a glittering 40-bout career.

Today, at the age of 55, Sugar Ray remains as popular as ever with fight fans across the globe and is still passionate about the sport that made him a superstar.

Click the video below to see what he had to say about the sweet science during an in-depth interview with GAVIN GLICKSMAN at Sun HQ.

pages.subdeck: YOU'RE THE MAN ... Damien Duff celebrates with Clint Dempsey
pages.headline: Fulham 2 Norwich 1
pages.teaser: CLINT DEMPSEY and Damien Duff ensured Cottagers' goalless run ended in style at Craven Cottage
pages.articlebody:
CLINT DEMPSEY and Damien Duff fired the goals that saw Fulham take down Norwich at Craven Cottage.

Martin Jol's side went into the game on the back of three without a goal  but arrested that slump with Dempsey's opener in the second minute.

Duff then doubled Fulham's advantage in the 13th, although an impressive first half showing was tempered by Pavel Pogrebnyak limping off injured.

Substitute Aaron Wilbraham's 77th minute effort led to a nervy ending by the Cottagers, who held onto end a three-match losing streak.

Fulham captain Danny Murphy had started along with forward Bryan Ruiz, as boss Jol shuffled his pack slightly.

Norwich handed a debut to January signing Ryan Bennett as manager Paul Lambert made four alterations to the side that defeated Wolves last weekend.

Any fears that Fulham's struggles in front of goal would continue against the Canaries were extinguished after just 107 seconds.

Ruiz latched onto a long ball, turned and saw a low drive saved by goalkeeper John Ruddy  with Dempsey bundling the ball home.

Norwich then enjoyed a spell of possession, but went further behind in the 13th minute.

Again the Canaries were caught out by a quick surge forward as Dempsey slotted the ball through to Duff, who curled home a left-footed effort from the edge of the box.

Mousa Dembele had a shot deflected as Fulham pushed for a third, before Dempsey twice saw headers go awry.

Elliott Ward picked up the game's first booking for a challenge on Ruiz in the midst of the Cottagers' dominance.

And there were calls from the home faithful for the centre-back's sending off after he was adjudged to have taken down Pogrebnyak minutes later.

The Russia international picked up a knock in the clash and was replaced in the 35th minute by debutant Alex Kacaniklic.

While struggling to control the match, Norwich were still looking dangerous in flashes and Jonny Howson wasted a gilt-edged chance to reduce the deficit by firing across the face of goal.

But only the goal frame and a last-ditch Bennett block prevented Fulham taking an unassailable lead on the stroke of half-time as Dempsey hit the post from an acute angle and Dembele saw his follow-up deflected behind.

Norwich boss Lambert brought on striker Simeon Jackson in place of defender Zak Whitbread for the second half in a 3-5-2 formation.

Kacaniklic was impressing on his Fulham debut and was unfortunate to see a superb right-footed curled effort tipped onto the crossbar by Ruddy four minutes after the restart.

Norwich tightened up soon after and attacked with renewed vigour, with mark Schwarzer doing well to stop a Wes Hoolahan drive before Aaron Hughes brilliantly blocked Andrew Surman.

Russell Martin headed straight at Schwarzer from the resulting corner, before David Fox collected a booking for scything down Dembele.

Surman saw a 25-yard free-kick deflect wide as the Canaries continued to press, efore Stephen Kelly burst through at the other end and was only thwarted by Bennett's late sliding tackle.

The chance began a change in momentum in the home side's favour, with Kacaniklic, Hughes and John Arne Riise all going close.

Fulham switched off in the final 15 minutes and duly conceded.

Moments after substitute Wilbraham inexplicably shot wide, he made amends by reducing the deficit 13 minutes from time as his effort deflected in off Hughes.

As Fulham began to rock, Norwich threw bodies forward and only last-gasp defending prevented Lambert's side finding another goal.

Schwarzer and his defence were being tested by the visitors, with Dickson Etuhu booked shortly after coming on against his former club.

Wilbraham and Kyle Naughton had efforts as the game came to a close, but the west Londoners held out.

Fulham: Schwarzer, Kelly, Hangeland, Hughes, John Arne Riise, Murphy (Diarra 71), Dembele, Ruiz (Etuhu 82), Dempsey, Duff, Pogrebnyak (Kacaniklic 35) Subs Not Used: Stockdale, Senderos, Frei, Trotta.

pages.subdeck: MERSEY SURE ... Everton celebrate as they overtake rivals Liverpool
pages.headline: Everton 2 West Brom 0
pages.teaser: EVERTON leapfrogged Merseyside rivals Liverpool as their amazing hot streak continued against West Brom
pages.articlebody:
EVERTON leapfrogged rivals Liverpool as their amzing hot streak continued.

The Toffees are now up into seventh thanks to an own goal from Gareth McAuley and Victor Anichebe's strike.

David Moyes' men have powered up the table since Christmas and are a point above their Merseyside foes.

The hosts made all the early runnings and Leon Osman and Darron Gibson came close early on.

The Toffees played in midweek yet showed no signs of tiredness  and broke the deadlock with an own goal on 18 minutes.

Osman picked the pull up, turned Liam Ridgewell, played a one-two with Nikica Jelavic  and hit his shot in off McAuley.

It was a wicked deflected that left keeper Ben Foster stranded.

On 30 minutes, West Brom almost levelled with their first chance.

Paul Scharner's shot was parried by Tim Howard, but when the ball fell to Chris Brunt the Baggies star crashed his effort against Shane Long.

At the other end, Marouane Fellaini's long-ranger forced Foster to tip the ball around the corner.

Just before the break, Keith Andrews raked his studs down the back of Fellaini's Achilles tendon.

But referee Peter Walton  in his final Premier League match before becoming general manager of the Professional Referee Organisation for the United States and Canada  awarded only a free-kick.

Jelavic was the centre of attention immediately after the interval.

The Croat had a half-chance from a corner that Foster caught easily before he was booked for catching Ridgewell.

The West Brom left-back was in the wars and Tim Cahill was next to be booked for fouling him.

Cahill was hooked on the hour, with Anichebe taking his place.

And it proved to be an inspired substitution as he doubled Everton's lead just eight minutes later.

He fired in off the far post to make it game, set and match to Moyes' men.

Everton: Howard, Hibbert, Jagielka, Heitinga, Baines, Osman (Gueye 46), Gibson, Fellaini, Pienaar, Cahill (Anichebe 62), Jelavic (McFadden 87). Subs Not Used: Mucha, Stracqualursi, Distin, Neville. Booked: Jelavic, Cahill.

pages.subdeck: ESCAPE FROM ALCARAZ ... Antolin Alcaraz celebrates opening the scoring
pages.headline: Wigan 2 Stoke 0
pages.teaser: ANTOLIN ALCARAZ and Victor Moses gave Wigan a priceless victory in their bid to stay up
pages.articlebody:
ANTOLIN ALCARAZ and Victor Moses gave Wigan a priceless victory in their bid to stay up.

Roberto Martinez's side had not won at home in the Premier League since August but were thankful to Paraguayan defender Alcaraz for powering home the opener in the 55th minute.

And in the last minute Moses slotted home to make sure of the points.

The result was not enough to lift Wigan out of the top three due to other results but could be vital in the race to avoid relegation.

Stoke, playing their 49th game of a hectic campaign, had the first chance when Ryan Shawcross got his head to a Pennant corner but Ali Al Habsi was alert.

Moments later a mistake from Andy Wilkinson let in Franco Di Santo, but the Argy striker never looked entirely confident running at Asmir Begovic who blocked the shot.

They continued to press for the opener and Begovic had to be alert to keep out Shaun Maloney's volley in the 15th minute, while Emmerson Boyce got on the end of a lovely cross from Jean Beausejour but his touch was heavy and Stoke cleared.

Wigan really only had themselves to blame for failing to take the lead five minutes before the break when Victor Moses sent a perfect cross along the six-yard line but Beausejour somehow failed to guide the ball into an empty net.

The bobbly pitch arguably did the winger no favours but it really was an astonishing miss and proved to be the last chance for either side as the first half ended goalless.

Wigan wanted a penalty in the opening minute of the second half when Dean Whitehead handled but Mark Clattenburg was unmoved despite being surrounded by Latics players.

Wigan kept pressing and probing and in the 55th minute they finally found a moment of precision to take the lead.

Maloney, who had caused Stoke problems all afternoon, played in Beausejour down the left and he made up for his horror miss with a lovely cross to pick out defender Alcaraz, who powered a header into the bottom corner.

Beausejour certainly had not worn his shooting boots and another golden chance went begging in the 72nd minute.

The winger was inexplicably left completely unmarked at the back post when Watson swung over a free-kick but again he scuffed his shot and Begovic saved easily.

The hosts made sure of the points in injury time when Wilkinson again wanted too much time and was robbed by Moses, who did what Di Santo could not, rounding Begovic and slotting home.

Wigan: Al Habsi, Alcaraz, Caldwell, Figueroa, Boyce, McCarthy, McArthur, Beausejour (Sammon 87), Moses, Di Santo (Gomez 81), Maloney (Ben Watson 70). Subs Not Used: Kirkland, Crusat, Jones, Stam.

Booked: Beausejour, Boyce. Goals: Alcaraz 54, Moses 90.
